<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
    <title>CKEditor Test</title>
    <script src="https://cdn.ckeditor.com/ckeditor5/40.2.0/classic/ckeditor.js"></script>
</head>
<body>
    <h1>CKEditor Test</h1>
    <div id="editor">
        <p>This is a test editor.</p>
        <p>You can edit this content!</p>
    </div>

    <button onclick="getContent()">Get Content</button>
    <button onclick="setContent()">Set Content</button>

    <script>
        let editor;

        ClassicEditor
            .create(document.querySelector('#editor'))
            .then(newEditor => {
                editor = newEditor;
                console.log('Editor initialized successfully');
            })
            .catch(error => {
                console.error('Editor initialization failed:', error);
            });

        function getContent() {
            if (editor) {
                alert(editor.getData());
            }
        }

        function setContent() {
            if (editor) {
                editor.setData('<p>New content set programmatically!</p>');
            }
        }
    </script>
</body>
</html>

    <main class="content">
        <section class="hero">
            <h1>InjectDependencies</h1>
            <p>Inject dependencies into objects created outside the container.</p>
            <div class="meta">Foundation/Container/Act/Inject/InjectDependencies.php</div>
        </section>

        <section class="section">
            <h2>Class Overview</h2>
            <div class="card">
                <p>InjectDependencies applies property and method injection based on #[Inject] attributes.</p>
                <details class="more">
                    <summary>More</summary>
                    <p>This service exists to bridge a common gap in enterprise systems: not every object is created by
                        the container. Factories, frameworks, and legacy modules often build objects manually.
                        InjectDependencies lets you bring those objects into the container's dependency model without
                        rewriting their constructors.</p>
                    <p>It uses a pre-analyzed <em>ServicePrototype</em> to discover injection points, then resolves
                        dependencies with the same rules used for normal container resolution. That keeps your injection
                        behavior consistent across the codebase.</p>
                    <p><strong>Terminology:</strong></p>
                    <p><em>Injection point</em>: a property or method marked with #[Inject].</p>
                    <p><em>Property injection</em>: assigning a resolved dependency directly to a property.</p>
                    <p><em>Method injection</em>: invoking a method with resolved parameters.</p>
                    <p><em>Overrides</em>: explicit values passed at runtime that take precedence over automatic
                        resolution.</p>
                </details>
            </div>
        </section>

        <section class="section">
            <h2>Story Example</h2>
            <div class="card">
                <p>Manual object creation, then injection.</p>
                <div class="example">class ReportService {
                    #[Inject]
                    private LoggerInterface $logger;

                    #[Inject]
                    public function configure(Config $config): void {}
                    }

                    $service = new ReportService(); // created outside container
                    $injector->execute($service);
                </div>
                <details class="more">
                    <summary>More</summary>
                    <p>In this story, the object is created manually. The container still knows how to resolve <span
                            class="code">LoggerInterface</span> and <span class="code">Config</span>, so
                        InjectDependencies applies them after construction.</p>
                    <p>Internally, the injector reads the prototype metadata, resolves each dependency using the
                        ResolutionEngine, and then writes the value into the property or calls the method with resolved
                        parameters.</p>
                </details>
            </div>
        </section>

        <section class="section">
            <h2>Methods</h2>

            <div class="card" id="execute">
                <h3>execute</h3>
                <p>Inject dependencies into an existing object.</p>
                <details class="more">
                    <summary>More</summary>
                    <p>This is the primary entry point. It builds or reuses a ServicePrototype, prepares a
                        ResolutionContext, and then runs the property and method phases in order.</p>
                    <p>Overrides always win. If you provide an override for a property or parameter, the injector uses
                        it instead of resolving through the engine.</p>
                    <p>If a dependency cannot be resolved and the target is not optional, the injector fails fast with a
                        ResolutionException. This keeps failures explicit and debuggable.</p>
                </details>
            </div>

            <div class="card" id="injectProperties">
                <h3>injectProperties</h3>
                <p>Assign resolved values into injectable properties.</p>
                <details class="more">
                    <summary>More</summary>
                    <p>Property injection is a direct assignment step. The injector resolves the value, then writes it
                        into the property using reflection (skipping readonly properties).</p>
                    <p>Resolution uses the PropertyInjector strategy: overrides first, then type resolution, then
                        default or null fallback, then unresolved.</p>
                </details>
            </div>

            <div class="card" id="injectMethods">
                <h3>injectMethods</h3>
                <p>Invoke injectable methods with resolved parameters.</p>
                <details class="more">
                    <summary>More</summary>
                    <p>Method injection is used for configuration or initialization hooks. Each method is invoked with
                        arguments resolved through the same engine rules as constructor injection.</p>
                    <p>This keeps method injection deterministic: parameter order is preserved, defaults are respected,
                        and overrides still take precedence.</p>
                </details>
            </div>
        </section>
    </main>
</div>
</body>
</html>

    <main class="content">
        <section class="hero">
            <h1>PropertyInjector</h1>
            <p>Single-step property resolution for injection.</p>
            <div class="meta">Foundation/Container/Act/Inject/PropertyInjector.php</div>
        </section>

        <section class="section">
            <h2>Class Overview</h2>
            <div class="card">
                <p>PropertyInjector resolves a single property value using a direct if/else strategy.</p>
                <details class="more">
                    <summary>More</summary>
                    <p>This class replaces the old chain-of-responsibility approach. The goal is to remove runtime
                        overhead and make the decision path explicit and predictable.</p>
                    <p>The resolution order is fixed:</p>
                    <p>1) Overrides (explicit values) always win.</p>
                    <p>2) Type resolution via the ResolutionEngine if the property has a resolvable type.</p>
                    <p>3) Default values, if the property declares one.</p>
                    <p>4) Nullable fallback.</p>
                    <p>5) Unresolved (skip injection).</p>
                </details>
            </div>
        </section>

        <section class="section">
            <h2>Methods</h2>

            <div class="card" id="resolve">
                <h3>resolve</h3>
                <p>Resolve a single property value for injection.</p>
                <details class="more">
                    <summary>More</summary>
                    <p>This method enforces a strict and easy-to-debug order. It is intentionally boring: no pipelines,
                        no chains, no DSL.</p>
                    <p>If a type cannot be resolved, it falls through to defaults or nullability rules. Required
                        properties that cannot be resolved remain unresolved so the caller can decide how to handle
                        them.</p>
                </details>
            </div>
        </section>
    </main>
</div>
</body>
</html>

        <main class="content">
            <section class="hero">
                <h1>LazyInterface</h1>
                <p class="lead">Contract for lazy value implementations.</p>
                <div class="meta">Foundation/Container/Features/Actions/Advanced/Lazy/LazyInterface.php</div>
            </section>

            <section class="section">
                <h2>Quick Summary</h2>
                <div class="card">
                    <p><strong>LazyInterface</strong> defines the contract for objects that provide lazy value
                        resolution. Any class implementing this interface must provide a <code>get()</code> method that
                        returns the resolved value.</p>
                </div>
            </section>

            <section class="section">
                <h2>Interface Definition</h2>
                <div class="card">
                    <pre><code class="language-php">interface LazyInterface
{
    public function get(): mixed;
}</code></pre>
                    <p>Simple contract with a single method for retrieving the lazy value.</p>
                </div>
            </section>

            <section class="section">
                <h2>Implementations</h2>
                <div class="card">
                    <ul class="related-links">
                        <li>
                            <a href="LazyValue.html"><strong>LazyValue</strong></a>
                            <p>Standard implementation with closure-based lazy loading</p>
                        </li>
                    </ul>
                </div>
            </section>
        </main>
    </div>
</body>

</html>
=== classes/Actions/Advanced/Lazy/LazyValue.html ===

        <main class="content">
            <section class="hero">
                <h1>LazyValue</h1>
                <p class="lead">Defers expensive service creation until the value is actually needed.</p>
                <div class="meta">Foundation/Container/Features/Actions/Advanced/Lazy/LazyValue.php</div>
            </section>

            <section class="section">
                <h2>Quick Summary</h2>
                <div class="card">
                    <p><strong>LazyValue</strong> wraps a factory closure and only executes it when <code>get()</code>
                        is called for the first time. This enables lazy loading of expensive services, improving
                        application startup time.</p>
                </div>
            </section>

            <section class="section">
                <h2>Story Example: Lazy Database Connection</h2>
                <div class="card">
                    <h3>Scenario: Expensive Service That's Rarely Used</h3>
                    <p>You have a <code>ReportGenerator</code> that needs a database connection, but reports are only
                        generated occasionally:</p>

                    <pre><code class="language-php">use Avax\Container\Features\Actions\Advanced\Lazy\LazyValue;

// Without LazyValue - connects immediately (slow startup!)
$db = new DatabaseConnection('host', 'user', 'pass');
$generator = new ReportGenerator($db);

// With LazyValue - connects only when needed (fast startup!)
$lazyDb = new LazyValue(fn() => new DatabaseConnection('host', 'user', 'pass'));
$generator = new ReportGenerator($lazyDb);

// No connection yet! ✓

// Later, when report is actually generated:
$report = $generator->generate();
// NOW the connection is created! ✓</code></pre>

                    <details class="more">
                        <summary>How It Works Internally</summary>
                        <ol>
                            <li><strong>Construction:</strong> Store the factory closure, don't execute it.</li>
                            <li><strong>First get():</strong> Execute factory, cache result, mark as initialized.</li>
                            <li><strong>Subsequent get():</strong> Return cached value immediately (no re-execution).
                            </li>
                            <li><strong>Exception Safety:</strong> If factory throws, mark as initialized to prevent
                                retry loops.</li>
                        </ol>
                        <pre><code class="language-php">$lazy = new LazyValue(fn() => expensiveOperation());

// First call - executes factory
$value1 = $lazy->get(); // expensiveOperation() runs

// Second call - returns cached value
$value2 = $lazy->get(); // No execution, returns cached

// $value1 === $value2 ✓</code></pre>
                    </details>
                </div>
            </section>

            <section class="section">
                <h2>How It Works</h2>
                <div class="card">
                    <h3>Lazy Initialization Pattern</h3>
                    <p>LazyValue implements the classic <strong>Lazy Initialization</strong> pattern with thread-safe
                        execution guarantees:</p>

                    <div class="workflow">
                        <div class="workflow-step">
                            <h4>State: Uninitialized</h4>
                            <p><code>$initialized = false</code></p>
                            <p><code>$value = null</code></p>
                        </div>
                        <div class="workflow-arrow">↓ get() called</div>
                        <div class="workflow-step">
                            <h4>Execute Factory</h4>
                            <p><code>$value = ($factory)()</code></p>
                            <p>Mark <code>$initialized = true</code></p>
                        </div>
                        <div class="workflow-arrow">↓ subsequent get()</div>
                        <div class="workflow-step">
                            <h4>Return Cached</h4>
                            <p>Skip factory execution</p>
                            <p>Return <code>$value</code> immediately</p>
                        </div>
                    </div>

                    <details class="more">
                        <summary>Edge Cases & Error Handling</summary>

                        <h4>Factory Throws Exception</h4>
                        <pre><code class="language-php">$lazy = new LazyValue(fn() => throw new RuntimeException('Failed!'));

try {
    $lazy->get(); // Throws RuntimeException
} catch (RuntimeException $e) {
    // Exception propagates
}

// Second call - STILL throws (factory not re-executed)
$lazy->get(); // Returns null (marked initialized)</code></pre>

                        <h4>Factory Returns Null</h4>
                        <pre><code class="language-php">$lazy = new LazyValue(fn() => null);
$value = $lazy->get(); // null is valid!</code></pre>

                        <h4>Container Integration</h4>
                        <pre><code class="language-php">// Container can inject LazyValue
class Service
{
    public function __construct(
        private LazyValue $expensiveService
    ) {}
    
    public function doWork()
    {
        // Only resolve when needed
        $service = $this->expensiveService->get();
        $service->process();
    }
}</code></pre>
                    </details>
                </div>
            </section>

            <section class="section">
                <h2>Architecture</h2>
                <div class="card">
                    <h3>Role in Container Ecosystem</h3>
                    <p>LazyValue is an <strong>optional optimization</strong> for expensive services:</p>

                    <div class="architecture-flow">
                        <div class="flow-step">
                            <strong>1. Service Definition</strong>
                            <p>Wrap factory in LazyValue</p>
                        </div>
                        <div class="flow-arrow">→</div>
                        <div class="flow-step">
                            <strong>2. Injection</strong>
                            <p>LazyValue injected (fast!)</p>
                        </div>
                        <div class="flow-arrow">→</div>
                        <div class="flow-step">
                            <strong>3. First Use</strong>
                            <p>Factory executes on get()</p>
                        </div>
                        <div class="flow-arrow">→</div>
                        <div class="flow-step">
                            <strong>4. Cached</strong>
                            <p>Subsequent calls instant</p>
                        </div>
                    </div>

                    <details class="more">
                        <summary>When to Use LazyValue</summary>
                        <h4>✓ Good Use Cases:</h4>
                        <ul>
                            <li>Database connections that aren't always needed</li>
                            <li>External API clients (HTTP, SOAP, etc.)</li>
                            <li>Heavy computation or file I/O</li>
                            <li>Services with expensive constructors</li>
                        </ul>

                        <h4>✗ Avoid For:</h4>
                        <ul>
                            <li>Lightweight objects (overhead not worth it)</li>
                            <li>Services always used (no benefit)</li>
                            <li>Critical path operations (adds indirection)</li>
                        </ul>
                    </details>
                </div>
            </section>

            <section class="section">
                <h2>Related Components</h2>
                <div class="card">
                    <h3>Explore Related Documentation</h3>
                    <ul class="related-links">
                        <li>
                            <a href="LazyInterface.html"><strong>LazyInterface</strong></a>
                            <p>Contract for lazy value implementations</p>
                        </li>
                        <li>
                            <a href="../../Resolve/Engine.html"><strong>ResolutionEngine</strong></a>
                            <p>Can wrap services in LazyValue automatically</p>
                        </li>
                        <li>
                            <a href="../../../Core/Enum/ServiceLifetime.html"><strong>ServiceLifetime</strong></a>
                            <p>Combine with Singleton for lazy singletons</p>
                        </li>
                        <li>
                            <a href="../../Instantiate/Instantiator.html"><strong>Instantiator</strong></a>
                            <p>Creates instances that LazyValue can wrap</p>
                        </li>
                    </ul>
                </div>
            </section>

            <section class="section">
                <h2>Performance Impact</h2>
                <div class="card">
                    <h3>Benchmarks & Optimization</h3>
                    <details class="more">
                        <summary>Performance Characteristics</summary>
                        <table>
                            <tr>
                                <th>Operation</th>
                                <th>Cost</th>
                                <th>Notes</th>
                            </tr>
                            <tr>
                                <td>Construction</td>
                                <td>~0.001ms</td>
                                <td>Just stores closure</td>
                            </tr>
                            <tr>
                                <td>First get()</td>
                                <td>Factory cost + ~0.002ms</td>
                                <td>Executes factory once</td>
                            </tr>
                            <tr>
                                <td>Subsequent get()</td>
                                <td>~0.0001ms</td>
                                <td>Returns cached value</td>
                            </tr>
                        </table>
                        <p><strong>Memory:</strong> ~200 bytes overhead per LazyValue instance.</p>
                    </details>
                </div>
            </section>
        </main>
    </div>
</body>

</html>

            </div>
            <div class="nav-section">
                <h3 class="nav-title">Think/Cache</h3>
                <ul class="nav-list">
                    <li><a href="../../Think/Cache/FilePrototypeCache.html">FilePrototypeCache</a></li>
                </ul>
            </div>

                <ul class="nav-list">

                </ul>

                <h3 class="nav-title">Think/Prototype</h3>
                <ul class="nav-list">
                    <li><a href="../../Think/Prototype/ServicePrototypeFactory.html">ServicePrototypeFactory</a></li>
                </ul>
            </div>
            <div class="nav-section">
                <h3 class="nav-title">Think/Prototype/Contracts</h3>
                <ul class="nav-list">
                    <li><a href="../../Think/Prototype/Contracts/ServicePrototypeFactoryInterface.html">ServicePrototypeFactoryInterface</a></li>
                </ul>
            </div>
            <div class="nav-section">
                <h3 class="nav-title">Think/Verify</h3>
                <ul class="nav-list">
                    <li><a href="../../Think/Verify/VerifyPrototype.html">VerifyPrototype</a></li>
                </ul>
            </div>
            <div class="nav-section">
                <h3 class="nav-title">Guidelines</h3>
                <ul class="nav-list">
                    <li><a href="../../../master-prompt.html">Master Prompt</a></li>

            </div>
        </nav>
    </aside>
        <main class="content">
            <section class="hero">
                <h1>InjectDependencies</h1>
                <p>Injects dependencies into an already-instantiated object.</p>
                <div class="meta">Foundation/Container/Features/Actions/Inject/InjectDependencies.php</div>
            </section>

            <section class="section">
                <h2>Class Overview</h2>
                <div class="card">
                    <p>Handles property and method injection for objects that have already been created.</p>
                    <details class="more">
                        <summary>More</summary>
                        <p>This is used for "post-construction" injection scenarios, such as:</p>
                        <ul>
                            <li>Properties marked with <code>#[Inject]</code>.</li>
                            <li>Setter methods marked with <code>#[Inject]</code>.</li>
                        </ul>
                        <p>It uses the <a href="../../Think/Model/ServicePrototype.html">ServicePrototype</a> to know
                            which properties/methods need injection, then
                            delegates to <a href="PropertyInjector.html">PropertyInjector</a> and <a
                                href="../../Resolve/DependencyResolver.html">DependencyResolver</a> to resolve the
                            actual
                            values.</p>
                    </details>
                </div>
            </section>

            <section class="section">
                <h2>Story Example</h2>
                <div class="card">
                    <h3>Scenario: Legacy Service Migration</h3>
                    <p>You have a legacy <code>EmailService</code> that was instantiated manually, but now you want to
                        inject a <code>Logger</code> into it:</p>
                    <pre><code class="language-php">class EmailService
{
    #[Inject]
    private Logger $logger;
    
    #[Inject]
    public function setCache(CacheInterface $cache): void
    {
        $this->cache = $cache;
    }
}

// Legacy code created the service
$emailService = new EmailService();

// Now inject dependencies
$container->injectInto($emailService);
// Logger and Cache are now injected!</code></pre>
                    <details class="more">
                        <summary>How It Works</summary>
                        <ol>
                            <li><strong>Analyze:</strong> <a
                                    href="../../Think/Prototype/ServicePrototypeFactory.html">ServicePrototypeFactory</a>
                                creates a prototype for <code>EmailService</code>.</li>
                            <li><strong>Property Injection:</strong> <a
                                    href="PropertyInjector.html">PropertyInjector</a> resolves <code>$logger</code> from
                                the container.</li>
                            <li><strong>Method Injection:</strong> <code>setCache()</code> is called with resolved
                                <code>CacheInterface</code>.</li>
                            <li><strong>Result:</strong> Fully configured service without changing constructor.</li>
                        </ol>
                        <p><strong>Related:</strong> <a href="../Instantiate/Instantiator.html">Instantiator</a> (for
                            constructor injection), <a href="../../Core/Attribute/Inject.html">#[Inject] Attribute</a>
                        </p>
                    </details>
                </div>
            </section>
        </main>
    </div>
</body>

</html>
=== classes/Actions/Inject/PropertyInjector.html ===

        <main class="content">
            <section class="hero">
                <h1>PropertyInjector</h1>
                <p>Resolves values for individual injectable properties.</p>
                <div class="meta">Foundation/Container/Features/Actions/Inject/PropertyInjector.php</div>
            </section>

            <section class="section">
                <h2>Class Overview</h2>
                <div class="card">
                    <p>Takes a <em>PropertyPrototype</em> and determines what value should be injected into it.</p>
                    <details class="more">
                        <summary>More</summary>
                        <p>Resolution logic:</p>
                        <ol>
                            <li>Check if there's an override provided.</li>
                            <li>Try to resolve the property's type from the container.</li>
                            <li>Fall back to default value or null if allowed.</li>
                            <li>Throw exception if the property is required and cannot be resolved.</li>
                        </ol>
                    </details>
                </div>
            </section>
        </main>
    </div>
</body>

</html>
=== classes/Actions/Inject/Resolvers/PropertyResolution.html ===

</head>

    <div class="layout">
                                <aside class="sidebar">

            <input type="text" class="search-input" placeholder="Search...">
        </div>

                    <li><a href="../../../Act/Inject/PropertyInjector.html">PropertyInjector</a></li>
                </ul>
            </div>
            <div class="nav-section">
                <h3 class="nav-title">Actions/Advanced/Lazy</h3>
                <ul class="nav-list">
                    <li><a href="../../Advanced/Lazy/LazyInterface.html">LazyInterface</a></li>

                <ul class="nav-list">
                    <li><a href="../InjectDependencies.html">InjectDependencies</a></li>
                    <li><a href="../PropertyInjector.html">PropertyInjector</a></li>
                </ul>
            </div>
            <div class="nav-section">
                <h3 class="nav-title">Actions/Inject/Resolvers</h3>
                <ul class="nav-list">
                    <li><a href="PropertyResolution.html">PropertyResolution</a></li>
                </ul>
            </div>
            <div class="nav-section">
                <h3 class="nav-title">Actions/Instantiate</h3>
                <ul class="nav-list">
                    <li><a href="../../Instantiate/Instantiator.html">Instantiator</a></li>
                </ul>
            </div>

        <main class="content">
            <section class="hero">
                <h1>PropertyResolution</h1>
                <p>Result object for property injection resolution.</p>
                <div class="meta">Foundation/Container/Features/Actions/Inject/Resolvers/PropertyResolution.php</div>
            </section>

            <section class="section">
                <h2>Class Overview</h2>
                <div class="card">
                    <p>Simple DTO that indicates whether a property was successfully resolved and what value to inject.
                    </p>
                    <details class="more">
                        <summary>More</summary>
                        <p>Two factory methods:</p>
                        <ul>
                            <li><strong>resolved($value):</strong> Property was successfully resolved with the given
                                value.</li>
                            <li><strong>unresolved():</strong> Property could not be resolved (will use default or
                                skip).</li>
                        </ul>
                    </details>
                </div>
            </section>
        </main>
    </div>
</body>

</html>

        <main class="content">
            <section class="hero">
                <h1>Instantiator</h1>
                <p class="lead">Creates new instances of classes with automatic constructor dependency injection.</p>
                <div class="meta">Foundation/Container/Features/Actions/Instantiate/Instantiator.php</div>
            </section>

            <section class="section">
                <h2>Quick Summary</h2>
                <div class="card">
                    <p><strong>Instantiator</strong> is responsible for the "new" operation in dependency injection. It
                        analyzes constructor parameters, resolves dependencies, and creates fresh instances with all
                        dependencies injected.</p>
                </div>
            </section>

            <section class="section">
                <h2>Story Example: Creating a UserService</h2>
                <div class="card">
                    <h3>Scenario: Automatic Constructor Injection</h3>
                    <p>You have a <code>UserService</code> that needs a repository and logger:</p>

                    <pre><code class="language-php">class UserService
{
    public function __construct(
        private UserRepository $repository,
        private Logger $logger
    ) {}
    
    public function createUser(array $data): User
    {
        $this->logger->info('Creating user', $data);
        return $this->repository->create($data);
    }
}

// Container automatically resolves dependencies
$userService = $container->make(UserService::class);
// Instantiator created UserService with injected dependencies!</code></pre>

                    <details class="more">
                        <summary>Step-by-Step Process</summary>
                        <ol>
                            <li><strong>Get Prototype:</strong> <a
                                    href="../../Think/Prototype/ServicePrototypeFactory.html">ServicePrototypeFactory</a>
                                provides <code>UserService</code> prototype.</li>
                            <li><strong>Analyze Constructor:</strong> Finds 2 parameters: <code>UserRepository</code>
                                and <code>Logger</code>.</li>
                            <li><strong>Resolve Dependencies:</strong> <a
                                    href="../Resolve/DependencyResolver.html">DependencyResolver</a> resolves both from
                                container.</li>
                            <li><strong>Create Instance:</strong> Calls
                                <code>new UserService($repository, $logger)</code>.</li>
                            <li><strong>Return:</strong> Fully configured instance ready to use.</li>
                        </ol>
                        <p><strong>Note:</strong> This happens <em>before</em> property/method injection by <a
                                href="../Inject/InjectDependencies.html">InjectDependencies</a>.</p>
                    </details>
                </div>
            </section>

            <section class="section">
                <h2>How It Works</h2>
                <div class="card">
                    <h3>Constructor Injection Workflow</h3>
                    <p>Instantiator follows a precise workflow to ensure correct object creation:</p>

                    <div class="workflow">
                        <div class="workflow-step">
                            <h4>1. Validation</h4>
                            <p>Check if class exists and is instantiable</p>
                            <code>class_exists($class) && $reflection->isInstantiable()</code>
                        </div>
                        <div class="workflow-step">
                            <h4>2. Prototype Retrieval</h4>
                            <p>Get cached analysis or analyze class</p>
                            <code>$prototype = $factory->createFor($class)</code>
                        </div>
                        <div class="workflow-step">
                            <h4>3. Parameter Resolution</h4>
                            <p>Resolve all constructor parameters</p>
                            <code>$params = $resolver->resolveParameters(...)</code>
                        </div>
                        <div class="workflow-step">
                            <h4>4. Instantiation</h4>
                            <p>Create instance with resolved parameters</p>
                            <code>$reflection->newInstanceArgs($params)</code>
                        </div>
                    </div>

                    <details class="more">
                        <summary>Handling Edge Cases</summary>
                        <h4>No Constructor</h4>
                        <pre><code class="language-php">class SimpleService
{
    // No constructor
}

// Instantiator calls: new SimpleService()</code></pre>

                        <h4>Constructor with Overrides</h4>
                        <pre><code class="language-php">$service = $container->make(UserService::class, [
    'logger' => new NullLogger() // Override specific dependency
]);</code></pre>

                        <h4>Non-Instantiable Classes</h4>
                        <pre><code class="language-php">abstract class AbstractService {}

// Throws: ContainerException
// "Cannot autowire: class [AbstractService] is not instantiable."</code></pre>
                    </details>
                </div>
            </section>

            <section class="section">
                <h2>Architecture</h2>
                <div class="card">
                    <h3>Role in Resolution Pipeline</h3>
                    <p>Instantiator is the <strong>"Build"</strong> step in the container's resolution pipeline:</p>

                    <div class="architecture-flow">
                        <div class="flow-step">
                            <strong>1. <a href="../Resolve/Engine.html">ResolutionEngine</a></strong>
                            <p>Orchestrates resolution</p>
                        </div>
                        <div class="flow-arrow">→</div>
                        <div class="flow-step active">
                            <strong>2. Instantiator</strong>
                            <p>Creates instance</p>
                        </div>
                        <div class="flow-arrow">→</div>
                        <div class="flow-step">
                            <strong>3. <a href="../Inject/InjectDependencies.html">InjectDependencies</a></strong>
                            <p>Property/method injection</p>
                        </div>
                        <div class="flow-arrow">→</div>
                        <div class="flow-step">
                            <strong>4. Return</strong>
                            <p>Fully configured service</p>
                        </div>
                    </div>

                    <details class="more">
                        <summary>Component Dependencies</summary>
                        <ul>
                            <li><a href="../../Think/Prototype/ServicePrototypeFactory.html">ServicePrototypeFactory</a>
                                - Provides class analysis</li>
                            <li><a href="../Resolve/DependencyResolver.html">DependencyResolver</a> - Resolves
                                constructor parameters</li>
                            <li><a href="../../Think/Model/ServicePrototype.html">ServicePrototype</a> - Contains
                                constructor metadata</li>
                            <li><a href="../../Think/Model/MethodPrototype.html">MethodPrototype</a> - Constructor
                                specification</li>
                            <li><a href="../../Think/Model/ParameterPrototype.html">ParameterPrototype</a> - Parameter
                                details</li>
                        </ul>
                    </details>
                </div>
            </section>

            <section class="section">
                <h2>Related Components</h2>
                <div class="card">
                    <h3>Explore Related Documentation</h3>
                    <ul class="related-links">
                        <li>
                            <a href="../Inject/InjectDependencies.html"><strong>InjectDependencies</strong></a>
                            <p>Handles post-construction property and method injection</p>
                        </li>
                        <li>
                            <a href="../Resolve/DependencyResolver.html"><strong>DependencyResolver</strong></a>
                            <p>Resolves individual parameters from the container</p>
                        </li>
                        <li>
                            <a
                                href="../../Think/Prototype/ServicePrototypeFactory.html"><strong>ServicePrototypeFactory</strong></a>
                            <p>Provides cached class analysis for fast instantiation</p>
                        </li>
                        <li>
                            <a href="../Resolve/Engine.html"><strong>ResolutionEngine</strong></a>
                            <p>Orchestrates the entire resolution process</p>
                        </li>
                    </ul>
                </div>
            </section>

            <section class="section">
                <h2>Performance Considerations</h2>
                <div class="card">
                    <h3>Optimization Strategies</h3>
                    <details class="more">
                        <summary>Caching & Performance</summary>
                        <ul>
                            <li><strong>Prototype Caching:</strong> Class analysis is cached, avoiding repeated
                                reflection.</li>
                            <li><strong>Lazy Resolution:</strong> Dependencies are only resolved when needed.</li>
                            <li><strong>Context Passing:</strong> Metadata is passed through context to avoid
                                re-analysis.</li>
                        </ul>
                        <pre><code class="language-php">// First call: Analyzes UserService
$user1 = $container->make(UserService::class);

// Subsequent calls: Uses cached prototype (fast!)
$user2 = $container->make(UserService::class);</code></pre>
                    </details>
                </div>
            </section>
        </main>
    </div>
</body>

</html>

        <main class="content">
            <section class="hero">
                <h1>ReflectionCache</h1>
                <p>Simple cache for ReflectionFunctionAbstract instances.</p>
                <div class="meta">Foundation/Container/Features/Actions/Invoke/Cache/ReflectionCache.php</div>
            </section>

            <section class="section">
                <h2>Class Overview</h2>
                <div class="card">
                    <p>Stores reflection objects to avoid repeated reflection operations during invocation.</p>
                    <details class="more">
                        <summary>More</summary>
                        <p>Used by <em>InvocationExecutor</em> to cache reflection data for callables, improving
                            performance when the same callable is invoked multiple times.</p>
                    </details>
                </div>
            </section>
        </main>
    </div>
</body>

</html>

    <main class="content">
        <section class="hero">
            <h1>DiagnosticsFlow</h1>
            <p>Opt-in diagnostics and metrics for container resolution.</p>
            <div class="meta">Foundation/Container/Advanced/Observe/DiagnosticsFlow.php</div>
        </section>

        <section class="section">
            <h2>Class Overview</h2>
            <div class="card">
                <p>DiagnosticsFlow collects runtime signals such as metrics and timelines.
                    It stays out of the core path by default and becomes active only when you opt in.</p>
                <details class="more">
                    <summary>More</summary>
                    <p>Observability is essential in production, but it should not slow down
                        every resolution in local or test environments. This flow lets you attach
                        collectors, capture timings, and export telemetry when you explicitly need it.</p>
                </details>
            </div>
        </section>

        <section class="section">
            <h2>Story Example</h2>
            <div class="card">
                <p>Enable metrics and export JSON.</p>
                <div class="example">use Avax\Container\Advanced\Observe\DiagnosticsFlow;

                    $diagnostics = new DiagnosticsFlow($container, $metrics);
                    $diagnostics->monitor();

                    echo $diagnostics->exportJson();
                </div>
                <details class="more">
                    <summary>More</summary>
                    <p>This is typically turned on in staging or production when you need
                        to diagnose slow service construction or memory spikes.</p>
                </details>
            </div>
        </section>
    </main>
</div>
</body>
</html>

        <main class="content">
            <section class="hero">
                <h1>Telemetry</h1>
                <p>Observability and monitoring metrics for the container.</p>
                <div class="meta">Foundation/Container/Features/Actions/Advanced/Observe/Telemetry.php</div>
            </section>

            <section class="section">
                <h2>Class Overview</h2>
                <div class="card">
                    <p>Provides a fluent interface to access container metrics and health status.</p>
                    <details class="more">
                        <summary>More</summary>
                        <p>It acts as a bridge to the <em>CollectMetrics</em> service, allowing developers or monitoring
                            tools to easily export performance data (like resolution times, error counts) in JSON
                            format.</p>
                    </details>
                </div>
            </section>

            <section class="section">
                <h2>Methods</h2>
                <div class="card">
                    <h3>exportMetrics</h3>
                    <p>Returns a JSON string containing all collected metrics and a timestamp.</p>
                </div>
                <div class="card">
                    <h3>getHealthStatus</h3>
                    <p>Returns a quick health check array, useful for heartbeat endpoints.</p>
                </div>
            </section>
        </main>
    </div>
</body>

    <main class="content">
        <section class="hero">
            <h1>PolicyFlow</h1>
            <p>Opt-in guard layer for resolution policies.</p>
            <div class="meta">Foundation/Container/Advanced/Policy/PolicyFlow.php</div>
        </section>

        <section class="section">
            <h2>Class Overview</h2>
            <div class="card">
                <p>PolicyFlow configures and enforces resolution guards. It is intentionally
                    optional: core resolution remains fast and predictable, while security and
                    validation rules are applied only when you opt in.</p>
                <details class="more">
                    <summary>More</summary>
                    <p>Guards are useful when you want to constrain what can be resolved (for example,
                        a whitelist of namespaces or a maximum dependency depth). This gives you a
                        policy boundary for large enterprise systems without polluting the hot path.</p>
                </details>
            </div>
        </section>

        <section class="section">
            <h2>Story Example</h2>
            <div class="card">
                <p>Restrict resolution by tag.</p>
                <div class="example">use Avax\Container\Advanced\Policy\PolicyFlow;

                    $policy = new PolicyFlow($container, $guard);
                    $policy->strict()
                    ->allowTagged('public-api')
                    ->done();
                </div>
                <details class="more">
                    <summary>More</summary>
                    <p>This configuration enables strict guard mode, then allows a specific tag to resolve
                        without an explicit binding. It is typically enabled in production to prevent accidental
                        wiring of vendor code or debugging utilities.</p>
                </details>
            </div>
        </section>
    </main>
</div>
</body>
</html>



=== classes/Advanced/Policy/Security.html ===
<!doctype html>
<html lang="en">

<head>
    <meta charset="utf-8">
    <meta content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1" name="viewport">
    <title>Security</title>
    <link href="../../../styles.css" rel="stylesheet">
</head>

<body>
    <div class="layout">
                                <aside class="sidebar">
        <div class="brand"><a href="../../../index.html">Container Docs</a></div>
        <div class="search-container">
            <input type="text" class="search-input" placeholder="Search...">
        </div>
        <nav>
            <div class="nav-section">
                <h3 class="nav-title">Container (Root)</h3>
                <ul class="nav-list">
                    <li><a href="../../Container.html">Container</a></li>
                </ul>
            </div>
            <div class="nav-section">
                <h3 class="nav-title">Act/Inject</h3>
                <ul class="nav-list">
                    <li><a href="../../Act/Inject/InjectDependencies.html">InjectDependencies</a></li>
                    <li><a href="../../Act/Inject/PropertyInjector.html">PropertyInjector</a></li>
                </ul>
            </div>
            <div class="nav-section">
                <h3 class="nav-title">Actions/Advanced/Lazy</h3>
                <ul class="nav-list">
                    <li><a href="../../Actions/Advanced/Lazy/LazyInterface.html">LazyInterface</a></li>
                    <li><a href="../../Actions/Advanced/Lazy/LazyValue.html">LazyValue</a></li>
                </ul>

        <main class="content">
            <section class="hero">
                <h1>Security</h1>
                <p>Fluent DSL for configuring container security policies.</p>
                <div class="meta">Foundation/Container/Features/Actions/Advanced/Policy/Security.php</div>
            </section>

            <section class="section">
                <h2>Class Overview</h2>
                <div class="card">
                    <p>Allows for fluent configuration of the container's <em>Guard</em> system.</p>
                    <details class="more">
                        <summary>More</summary>
                        <p>It provides methods to enable strict mode, whitelist specific tags, or define other security
                            rules that the container must enforce during resolution.</p>
                    </details>
                </div>
            </section>
        </main>
    </div>
</body>

</html>

    <main class="content">
        <div class="hero">
            <h1>Container</h1>
            <p>The main facade class that provides your application's primary interface for dependency injection.</p>
            <div class="meta">
                <strong>File Path:</strong> Container.php<br>
                <strong>Folder Context:</strong> Root folder of the Container component<br>
                <strong>Generated:</strong> 2026-01-08
            </div>
        </div>

        <section class="section content-card" id="quick-summary">
            <h2>Quick Summary</h2>
            <p>This class acts as the public API for the entire dependency injection system. It delegates all heavy lifting to the ContainerKernel while providing a clean, simple interface that developers can rely on. Without this facade, developers would need to understand the complex internal machinery of kernels, pipelines, and scopes - this class makes dependency injection accessible and straightforward.</p>
            <p>The Container exists to provide a stable, simple API that applications can depend on. It hides the complexity of resolution engines, pipelines, scopes, and prototypes behind a thin wrapper.</p>
        </section>

        <section class="section content-card" id="terminology">
            <h2>Terminology</h2>
            <dl>
                <dt>Facade Pattern</dt>
                <dd>A design pattern where a simple interface is provided to hide the complexities of a larger system. The Container class is a facade over the ContainerKernel.</dd>
                <dt>Dependency Injection</dt>
                <dd>A technique where objects receive their dependencies from external sources rather than creating them internally.</dd>
                <dt>Service Resolution</dt>
                <dd>The process of converting a service identifier (like a class name) into a fully constructed and configured object instance.</dd>
                <dt>Autowiring</dt>
                <dd>Automatic dependency resolution based on constructor parameter types, without explicit configuration.</dd>
                <dt>Service Lifetime</dt>
                <dd>How long a service instance should live - singleton (application-wide), scoped (per request), or transient (new each time).</dd>
                <dt>Binding</dt>
                <dd>An explicit mapping from an abstract type (interface) to a concrete implementation class.</dd>
                <dt>Scope</dt>
                <dd>A context that defines the lifetime boundaries for service instances.</dd>
                <dt>Kernel</dt>
                <dd>The core engine that handles the actual work of dependency resolution and lifecycle management.</dd>
                <dt>Prototype</dt>
                <dd>A pre-analyzed blueprint of a class's dependencies, cached for performance.</dd>
                <dt>Injection</dt>
                <dd>The act of providing dependencies to an object through its constructor, properties, or methods.</dd>
            </dl>
        </section>

        <section class="section content-card" id="think-of-it">
            <h2>Think of It Like...</h2>
            <p>Imagine you're at a fancy restaurant. You don't go into the kitchen and try to cook your own meal - you tell the waiter what you want, and they coordinate with the kitchen to prepare it perfectly. The Container is like that waiter:</p>
            <ul>
                <li>You tell the waiter (Container) what dish you want ("I need a UserService")</li>
                <li>The waiter relays this to the kitchen (ContainerKernel) without you knowing the details</li>
                <li>The kitchen handles all the complex cooking, ingredient gathering, and plating</li>
                <li>You get a perfectly prepared meal without worrying about the behind-the-scenes work</li>
            </ul>
            <div class="table-wrapper">
                <table>
                    <thead>
                        <tr>
                            <th>Restaurant Experience</th>
                            <th>Dependency Injection</th>
                        </tr>
                    </thead>
                    <tbody>
                        <tr>
                            <td>Dining room with simple menu</td>
                            <td>Container API with clean methods</td>
                        </tr>
                        <tr>
                            <td>Waiter taking your order</td>
                            <td>Container.get() method call</td>
                        </tr>
                        <tr>
                            <td>Complex kitchen operations</td>
                            <td>ContainerKernel resolution pipeline</td>
                        </tr>
                        <tr>
                            <td>Chef managing ingredients and timing</td>
                            <td>Scope manager handling lifetimes</td>
                        </tr>
                        <tr>
                            <td>Perfectly plated meal delivered</td>
                            <td>Fully injected service instance returned</td>
                        </tr>
                    </tbody>
                </table>
            </div>
        </section>

        <section class="section content-card" id="story-example">
            <h2>Story Example</h2>
            <p>Let's say you're building a user management system. You have a <code>UserController</code> that needs to:</p>
            <ul>
                <li>Validate user input</li>
                <li>Check permissions</li>
                <li>Save to database</li>
                <li>Send notification emails</li>
                <li>Log the action</li>
            </ul>
            <h3>The Problem Without the Container</h3>
            <pre><code class="language-php">class UserController {
    private $validator;
    private $permissions;
    private $database;
    private $email;
    private $logger;
    
    public function __construct() {
        $this->validator = new UserValidator();
        $this->permissions = new PermissionChecker();
        $this->database = new DatabaseConnection('localhost');
        $this->email = new EmailService();
        $this->logger = new FileLogger('/var/log/app.log');
    }
    
    public function createUser($userData) {
        // Every controller has to know how to create its dependencies
        // This makes testing impossible and changes difficult
    }
}</code></pre>
            <h3>The Solution With Container</h3>
            <pre><code class="language-php">// In bootstrap.php
$container = new Container($kernel);

// Register services once
$container->bind(UserRepositoryInterface::class, SqlUserRepository::class);
$container->singleton(ValidatorInterface::class, UserValidator::class);

// In UserController.php
class UserController {
    public function __construct(
        private UserRepositoryInterface $users,
        private ValidatorInterface $validator,
        private PermissionChecker $permissions,
        private EmailService $email,
        private LoggerInterface $logger
    ) {}
    
    public function createUser(array $userData): User {
        // Just use the dependencies - no creation logic here
        $this->validator->validate($userData);
        $this->permissions->check('user.create');
        
        $user = $this->users->create($userData);
        $this->email->sendWelcome($user);
        $this->logger->info("User created: {$user->id}");
        
        return $user;
    }
}

// In your application
$userController = $container->get(UserController::class);
$newUser = $userController->createUser($requestData);</code></pre>
            <p>The Container class makes this possible by providing a simple <code>get()</code> method that hides all the complexity of creating UserController with its five dependencies, each of which might have their own dependencies.</p>
        </section>

        <section class="section content-card" id="for-dummies">
            <h2>For Dummies</h2>
            <p>Think of the Container class as your friendly neighborhood shopkeeper. You walk in and say "I need a bicycle," and they hand you a fully assembled bike with pedals, brakes, and everything working. You don't need to know how bikes are made or where the parts come from - you just get what you asked for.</p>
            <h3>What Problem Does This Class Solve?</h3>
            <p>Without the Container, every class in your application would need to know how to create its own helper objects. This leads to code like:</p>
            <pre><code class="language-php">class ReportGenerator {
    public function __construct() {
        $this->db = new Database('host', 'user', 'pass');
        $this->formatter = new ReportFormatter();
        $this->exporter = new PdfExporter();
    }
}</code></pre>
            <p>Problems with this approach:</p>
            <ul>
                <li><strong>Hard to test:</strong> Can't use fake database for tests</li>
                <li><strong>Hard to change:</strong> Want to use Excel export? Change everywhere</li>
                <li><strong>Tight coupling:</strong> ReportGenerator is stuck with specific classes</li>
                <li><strong>Configuration everywhere:</strong> Database credentials repeated in every class</li>
            </ul>
            <h3>How It Works (Simple Mental Model)</h3>
            <ol>
                <li><strong>Registration:</strong> You tell the Container how to create things (like "PdfExporter should be created with these settings")</li>
                <li><strong>Request:</strong> Your code asks the Container for what it needs ("I need a ReportGenerator")</li>
                <li><strong>Assembly:</strong> Container builds the ReportGenerator and automatically gives it a Database, ReportFormatter, and PdfExporter</li>
                <li><strong>Delivery:</strong> You get a ready-to-use ReportGenerator</li>
            </ol>
            <h3>Common Mistakes & Misconceptions</h3>
            <ul>
                <li><strong>Mistake:</strong> Creating the Container inside your classes</li>
                <li><strong>Why it's wrong:</strong> Makes classes hard to test and creates hidden dependencies</li>
                <li><strong>Fix:</strong> Container should only be used in "composition root" (bootstrap/application startup)</li>
            </ul>
            <ul>
                <li><strong>Mistake:</strong> Using <code>$container->get()</code> deep in business logic</li>
                <li><strong>Why it's wrong:</strong> Business logic shouldn't know about the container</li>
                <li><strong>Fix:</strong> Use constructor injection to get dependencies</li>
            </ul>
            <ul>
                <li><strong>Misconception:</strong> Container is slow</li>
                <li><strong>Reality:</strong> Modern containers are highly optimized with caching</li>
            </ul>
            <h3>FAQ</h3>
            <dl>
                <dt>Should I use the Container in my business logic?</dt>
                <dd>No! The Container should only be used at application startup to wire everything together. Your business classes should get their dependencies through constructors.</dd>
                <dt>What's the difference between get() and make()?</dt>
                <dd><code>get()</code> respects scopes and may return cached instances. <code>make()</code> always creates new instances and bypasses caching.</dd>
                <dt>How do I know what to register?</dt>
                <dd>Register interfaces to concrete classes, and singleton expensive objects. Most concrete classes can be auto-wired without registration.</dd>
                <dt>What if I need different configurations?</dt>
                <dd>Use the scope system - beginScope() creates a context where services can have different lifetimes or configurations.</dd>
            </dl>
        </section>

        <section class="section content-card" id="how-it-works">
            <h2>How It Works (Technical)</h2>
            <p>The Container class is a thin facade that delegates all operations to a ContainerKernel instance. The kernel handles the actual complexity while the Container provides a clean API.</p>
            <h3>Core Architecture</h3>
            <ul>
                <li><strong>Single Responsibility:</strong> Container handles API, Kernel handles implementation</li>
                <li><strong>Delegation Pattern:</strong> Every public method calls a corresponding kernel method</li>
                <li><strong>Immutable Interface:</strong> Once created, the Container's behavior is stable</li>
                <li><strong>PSR-11 Compliance:</strong> Follows standards for container interoperability</li>
            </ul>
            <h3>Resolution Flow</h3>
            <ol>
                <li><strong>Method Call:</strong> Application calls <code>$container->get('UserService')</code></li>
                <li><strong>Delegation:</strong> Container calls <code>$this->kernel->get('UserService')</code></li>
                <li><strong>Kernel Processing:</strong> Kernel runs through resolution pipeline</li>
                <li><strong>Return:</strong> Fully constructed service returned to application</li>
            </ol>
            <h3>Key Methods and Their Purposes</h3>
            <dl>
                <dt>get($id)</dt>
                <dd>Primary resolution method - returns cached or creates new instance</dd>
                <dt>has($id)</dt>
                <dd>Fast existence check without construction</dd>
                <dt>make($abstract, $parameters)</dt>
                <dd>Always creates new instance with optional overrides</dd>
                <dt>call($callable, $parameters)</dt>
                <dd>Executes callable with dependency injection</dd>
                <dt>injectInto($target)</dt>
                <dd>Adds dependencies to existing objects</dd>
            </dl>
            <h3>Performance Characteristics</h3>
            <ul>
                <li><strong>Memory:</strong> Minimal overhead - just holds kernel reference</li>
                <li><strong>Speed:</strong> Method calls are direct delegation with no processing</li>
                <li><strong>Thread Safety:</strong> Depends on kernel implementation</li>
                <li><strong>Caching:</strong> No caching at Container level - delegated to kernel</li>
            </ul>
        </section>

        <section class="section content-card" id="architecture-role">
            <h2>Architecture Role</h2>
            <p>The Container class serves as the main entry point for the entire dependency injection system. It lives at the boundary between application code and the container infrastructure, making DI accessible to developers while keeping the complexity contained.</p>
            <h3>What Depends on This Class</h3>
            <ul>
                <li>Application bootstrap/initialization code</li>
                <li>Framework integration layers</li>
                <li>Test setup and mocking utilities</li>
                <li>CLI commands and console applications</li>
                <li>Any code that needs to resolve services dynamically</li>
            </ul>
            <h3>What This Class Depends On</h3>
            <ul>
                <li><strong>ContainerKernel:</strong> The actual implementation that does the work</li>
                <li><strong>PSR Standards:</strong> PSR-11 Container interface compliance</li>
                <li><strong>PHP Types:</strong> Uses typed parameters and return values</li>
            </ul>
            <h3>How It Fits Into the Larger System</h3>
            <p>The Container acts as the composition root interface - the single, stable API that the entire application uses for dependency resolution. This design provides:</p>
            <ul>
                <li><strong>Stability:</strong> Application code depends on a simple interface that rarely changes</li>
                <li><strong>Testability:</strong> Easy to mock or replace in tests</li>
                <li><strong>Flexibility:</strong> Kernel can be swapped for different implementations</li>
                <li><strong>Separation:</strong> Business logic doesn't know about resolution details</li>
            </ul>
        </section>

        <section class="section content-card" id="risks-trade-offs">
            <h2>Risks, Trade-offs & Recommended Practices</h2>
            <h3>API Stability</h3>
            <p><strong>Risk:</strong> As a public API, changes to Container methods could break applications.</p>
            <p><strong>Why it matters:</strong> The Container is used throughout applications, so breaking changes have wide impact.</p>
            <p><strong>Design stance:</strong> Container maintains strict backward compatibility and follows semantic versioning.</p>
            <p><strong>Recommended practice:</strong> Treat Container methods as stable API, use dependency injection principles, and test against Container interfaces.</p>
            <h3>Performance Overhead</h3>
            <p><strong>Risk:</strong> Every method call involves delegation to the kernel.</p>
            <p><strong>Why it matters:</strong> Hot paths calling Container methods frequently could accumulate overhead.</p>
            <p><strong>Design stance:</strong> Delegation overhead is minimal and acceptable for the benefits gained.</p>
            <p><strong>Recommended practice:</strong> Avoid Container calls in tight loops, use constructor injection for frequently accessed services, and profile performance-critical code.</p>
            <h3>Testing Complexity</h3>
            <p><strong>Risk:</strong> Container usage can make unit tests more complex if not handled properly.</p>
            <p><strong>Why it matters:</strong> Poor testing practices with Container can lead to brittle, slow tests.</p>
            <p><strong>Design stance:</strong> Container is designed to be testable through proper dependency injection.</p>
            <p><strong>Recommended practice:</strong> Don't inject Container into business logic, use constructor injection, mock dependencies in tests, and keep Container usage confined to bootstrap code.</p>
            <h3>Error Handling</h3>
            <p><strong>Risk:</strong> Exceptions from kernel operations bubble up through Container methods.</p>
            <p><strong>Why it matters:</strong> Applications need to handle resolution failures gracefully.</p>
            <p><strong>Design stance:</strong> Container preserves original exceptions with full context.</p>
            <p><strong>Recommended practice:</strong> Handle ResolutionException and ServiceNotFoundException appropriately, provide meaningful error messages, and use has() for defensive programming.</p>
        </section>

        <section class="section content-card" id="related-files-folders">
            <h2>Related Files &amp; Folders</h2>
            <ul>
                <li><strong>Parent folder:</strong> Root Container component</li>
                <li><strong>Sibling files:</strong> Container.txt (notes), docs/index.html (overview)</li>
                <li><strong>Child folders:</strong> None (this is a single file)</li>
                <li><strong>Depends on:</strong> Core/ContainerKernel.php (the actual implementation)</li>
                <li><strong>Related interfaces:</strong> Core/Contracts/ContainerInternalInterface.php</li>
            </ul>
            <p><strong>Reading order:</strong> Start here (Container.php), then ContainerKernel.php to understand the implementation details.</p>
        </section>

        <section class="section content-card" id="methods">
            <h2>Methods</h2>
            <div id="get">
                <h3>get(string $id): mixed</h3>
                <p>Resolve a service by identifier. This is the primary method for retrieving services from the container.</p>
                <p><strong>Purpose:</strong> Get fully constructed service instances with all dependencies resolved.</p>
                <p><strong>When to use:</strong> When you need a service instance in application code.</p>
                <p><strong>Example:</strong> <code>$userService = $container->get(UserService::class);</code></p>
            </div>
            <div id="has">
                <h3>has(string $id): bool</h3>
                <p>Check if a service is registered or can be resolved without constructing it.</p>
                <p><strong>Purpose:</strong> Fast existence checking for conditional service usage.</p>
                <p><strong>When to use:</strong> When you need to check service availability without the cost of resolution.</p>
            </div>
            <div id="make">
                <h3>make(string $abstract, array $parameters = []): object</h3>
                <p>Create a new instance with optional parameters, bypassing scope caches.</p>
                <p><strong>Purpose:</strong> Always get fresh instances, useful for factories or contextual creation.</p>
                <p><strong>When to use:</strong> When you need multiple instances or want to override constructor parameters.</p>
            </div>
            <div id="call">
                <h3>call(callable|string $callable, array $parameters = []): mixed</h3>
                <p>Execute a callable with dependency injection applied to its parameters.</p>
                <p><strong>Purpose:</strong> Apply DI to functions, methods, or closures that weren't designed for constructor injection.</p>
                <p><strong>When to use:</strong> For event handlers, middleware, or legacy code that uses callables.</p>
            </div>
            <div id="injectInto">
                <h3>injectInto(object $target): object</h3>
                <p>Inject dependencies into an existing object instance.</p>
                <p><strong>Purpose:</strong> Add dependencies to objects created outside the container.</p>
                <p><strong>When to use:</strong> For legacy objects, deserialization, or factory-created instances.</p>
            </div>
            <div id="resolve">
                <h3>resolve(ServicePrototype $prototype): mixed</h3>
                <p>Resolve a service from a pre-computed prototype.</p>
                <p><strong>Purpose:</strong> Advanced API for performance optimization when you have prototypes.</p>
                <p><strong>When to use:</strong> In advanced scenarios with pre-analyzed service definitions.</p>
            </div>
            <div id="resolveContext">
                <h3>resolveContext(KernelContext $context): mixed</h3>
                <p>Resolve a service with additional context information.</p>
                <p><strong>Purpose:</strong> Provide contextual information for complex resolution scenarios.</p>
                <p><strong>When to use:</strong> When resolution depends on runtime context beyond just the service ID.</p>
            </div>
            <div id="instance">
                <h3>instance(string $abstract, object $instance): void</h3>
                <p>Register a shared instance for a given abstract.</p>
                <p><strong>Purpose:</strong> Make existing objects available through the container.</p>
                <p><strong>When to use:</strong> For external objects or pre-configured services.</p>
            </div>
            <div id="beginScope">
                <h3>beginScope(): void</h3>
                <p>Start a new resolution scope for scoped services.</p>
                <p><strong>Purpose:</strong> Create a boundary for scoped service lifetimes.</p>
                <p><strong>When to use:</strong> At the beginning of request processing or unit-of-work boundaries.</p>
            </div>
            <div id="endScope">
                <h3>endScope(): void</h3>
                <p>End the current resolution scope and clean up scoped instances.</p>
                <p><strong>Purpose:</strong> Clean up scoped services and prevent memory leaks.</p>
                <p><strong>When to use:</strong> At the end of request processing or unit-of-work boundaries.</p>
            </div>
            <div id="canInject">
                <h3>canInject(object $target): bool</h3>
                <p>Check if an object can receive dependency injection.</p>
                <p><strong>Purpose:</strong> Determine if injection is possible without attempting it.</p>
                <p><strong>When to use:</strong> For validation or conditional injection logic.</p>
            </div>
            <div id="inspectInjection">
                <h3>inspectInjection(object $target): InjectionReport</h3>
                <p>Get detailed information about injection points on an object.</p>
                <p><strong>Purpose:</strong> Analyze what would be injected for debugging or tooling.</p>
                <p><strong>When to use:</strong> In development tools or for injection debugging.</p>
            </div>
            <div id="scopes">
                <h3>scopes(): ScopeManager</h3>
                <p>Get the scope manager for advanced scope control.</p>
                <p><strong>Purpose:</strong> Provide direct access to scope management functionality.</p>
                <p><strong>When to use:</strong> For advanced scope manipulation (rarely needed).</p>
            </div>
            <div id="exportMetrics">
                <h3>exportMetrics(): string</h3>
                <p>Export performance and usage metrics as a string.</p>
                <p><strong>Purpose:</strong> Provide monitoring and performance analysis data.</p>
                <p><strong>When to use:</strong> For logging, monitoring dashboards, or performance analysis.</p>
            </div>
            <div id="getDefinitions">
                <h3>getDefinitions(): DefinitionStore</h3>
                <p>Get access to the internal service definition storage.</p>
                <p><strong>Purpose:</strong> Allow inspection and manipulation of service definitions.</p>
                <p><strong>When to use:</strong> In advanced tooling or container extensions.</p>
            </div>
        </section>
    </main>
</div>
</body>
</html>

        <main class="content">
            <section class="hero">
                <h1>Inject</h1>
                <p>Attribute to mark properties, methods, or parameters for dependency injection.</p>
                <div class="meta">Foundation/Container/Features/Core/Attribute/Inject.php</div>
            </section>

            <section class="section">
                <h2>Class Overview</h2>
                <div class="card">
                    <p>A native PHP 8 Attribute used to explicitly request dependency injection.</p>
                    <details class="more">
                        <summary>More</summary>
                        <p>It can be placed on properties to trigger property injection (even for private properties) or
                            on methods to mark them for container invocation.</p>
                        <p>It accepts an optional <code>abstract</code> parameter to specify exactly which service ID to
                            resolve, overriding type hints.</p>
                    </details>
                </div>
            </section>
        </main>
    </div>
</body>

</html>

    </aside>
        <main class="content">
            <section class="hero">
                <h1>Singleton</h1>
                <p>Attribute to mark a class as a Singleton.</p>
                <div class="meta">Foundation/Container/Features/Core/Attribute/Singleton.php</div>
            </section>

            <section class="section">
                <h2>Class Overview</h2>
                <div class="card">
                    <p>When this attribute is present on a class, the container automatically registers it as a
                        Singleton during auto-discovery.</p>
                    <details class="more">
                        <summary>More</summary>
                        <p>This allows for "Zero-Config" singletons. You don't need to manually define
                            <code>$builder->singleton(MyService::class)</code> if the class itself declares its
                            lifecycle intent.</p>
                    </details>
                </div>
            </section>
        </main>
    </div>
</body>

</html>

                <h3 class="nav-title">Invoke/Cache</h3>
