    <main class="content">
        <section class="hero">
            <h1>ScopePipe</h1>
            <p>Checks whether a scoped or singleton instance already exists.</p>
            <div class="meta">Foundation/Container/Act/Resolve/Pipeline/ScopePipe.php</div>
        </section>

        <section class="section">
            <h2>Class Overview</h2>
            <div class="card">
                <p>ScopePipe is the first gate in the resolution pipeline. It tries to return an already-created
                    instance from the scope manager before doing any new work.</p>
                <details class="more">
                    <summary>More</summary>
                    <p>This saves time and ensures shared services (singletons/scoped) remain stable during a request or
                        container lifetime.</p>
                </details>
            </div>
        </section>

        <section class="section">
            <h2>Methods</h2>
            <div class="card" id="handle">
                <h3>handle</h3>
                <p>Looks up the resolved service in the scope manager and returns it if present.</p>
                <details class="more">
                    <summary>More</summary>
                    <p>If the instance is found, the pipeline stops. Otherwise, the next pipe is called to continue
                        resolution.</p>
                </details>
            </div>
        </section>
    </main>
</div>
</body>
</html>

    <main class="content">
        <section class="hero">
            <h1>TerminalPipe</h1>
            <p>Final pipe that handles unresolved cases.</p>
            <div class="meta">Foundation/Container/Act/Resolve/Pipeline/TerminalPipe.php</div>
        </section>

        <section class="section">
            <h2>Class Overview</h2>
            <div class="card">
                <p>TerminalPipe is the last step. If earlier pipes could not resolve a service, this pipe triggers an
                    error or exception.</p>
                <details class="more">
                    <summary>More</summary>
                    <p>It prevents silent failures and ensures that unresolved dependencies are reported clearly.</p>
                </details>
            </div>
        </section>

        <section class="section">
            <h2>Methods</h2>
            <div class="card" id="handle">
                <h3>handle</h3>
                <p>Handles the final unresolved state and raises a resolution error.</p>
            </div>
        </section>
    </main>
</div>
</body>
</html>

                    <li><a href="../Think/Prototype/ServicePrototypeFactory.html">ServicePrototypeFactory</a></li>
                </ul>
            </div>
            <div class="nav-section">
                <h3 class="nav-title">Think/Prototype/Contracts</h3>
                <ul class="nav-list">
                    <li><a href="../Think/Prototype/Contracts/ServicePrototypeFactoryInterface.html">ServicePrototypeFactoryInterface</a></li>
                </ul>
            </div>
            <div class="nav-section">
                <h3 class="nav-title">Think/Verify</h3>
                <ul class="nav-list">
                    <li><a href="../Think/Verify/VerifyPrototype.html">VerifyPrototype</a></li>
                </ul>
            </div>
            <div class="nav-section">
                <h3 class="nav-title">Guidelines</h3>
                <ul class="nav-list">
                    <li><a href="../../master-prompt.html">Master Prompt</a></li>
                </ul>
            </div>
        </nav>
    </aside>
    <main class="content">
        <section class="hero">
            <h1>ResolutionContext</h1>
            <p>Immutable state holder for a single resolution request.</p>
            <div class="meta">Foundation/Container/Act/Resolve/ResolutionContext.php</div>
        </section>

        <section class="section">
            <h2>Class Overview</h2>
            <div class="card">
                <p>ResolutionContext carries the who/what/where of a resolution. It stores the service name, overrides,
                    depth, and parent so the engine can detect circular dependencies and provide accurate error
                    messages.</p>
                <details class="more">
                    <summary>More</summary>
                    <p>Imagine a breadcrumb trail. Each time the container resolves a dependency, it creates a child
                        context pointing back to its parent. If a service tries to resolve itself again, the context can
                        detect that loop.</p>
                </details>
            </div>
        </section>

        <section class="section">
            <h2>Methods</h2>

            <div class="card" id="__construct">
                <h3>__construct</h3>
                <p>Creates a new resolution context with service name, overrides, and lineage.</p>
                <details class="more">
                    <summary>More</summary>
                    <p>The context is immutable: once created, it does not change. New child contexts are created for
                        nested resolutions.</p>
                </details>
            </div>

            <div class="card" id="withEngine">
                <h3>withEngine</h3>
                <p>Returns a copy of the context with the resolution engine attached.</p>
                <details class="more">
                    <summary>More</summary>
                    <p>This is useful when recursive resolution needs a reference to the engine.</p>
                </details>
            </div>

            <div class="card" id="withPrototype">
                <h3>withPrototype</h3>
                <p>Returns a copy of the context with a precomputed prototype attached.</p>
                <details class="more">
                    <summary>More</summary>
                    <p>When a prototype is available, the engine can skip extra analysis steps.</p>
                </details>
            </div>

            <div class="card" id="child">
                <h3>child</h3>
                <p>Creates a child context for a nested dependency.</p>
                <details class="more">
                    <summary>More</summary>
                    <p>Every nested dependency gets its own context so the engine can track depth and prevent loops.</p>
                </details>
            </div>

            <div class="card" id="getAbstract">
                <h3>getAbstract</h3>
                <p>Returns the abstract identifier being resolved.</p>
            </div>

            <div class="card" id="getOverrides">
                <h3>getOverrides</h3>
                <p>Returns explicit parameter overrides supplied by the caller.</p>
            </div>

            <div class="card" id="getDepth">
                <h3>getDepth</h3>
                <p>Returns the depth of this resolution within the dependency graph.</p>
            </div>

            <div class="card" id="getParent">
                <h3>getParent</h3>
                <p>Returns the parent context, or null if this is the root.</p>
            </div>

            <div class="card" id="getEngine">
                <h3>getEngine</h3>
                <p>Returns the attached engine instance, if present.</p>
            </div>

            <div class="card" id="getPrototype">
                <h3>getPrototype</h3>
                <p>Returns the attached prototype, if present.</p>
            </div>

            <div class="card" id="contains">
                <h3>contains</h3>
                <p>Checks whether the resolution path already contains a given identifier.</p>
                <details class="more">
                    <summary>More</summary>
                    <p>This is used to detect circular dependencies like A → B → A.</p>
                </details>
            </div>

            <div class="card" id="getPath">
                <h3>getPath</h3>
                <p>Returns a string path of the resolution chain.</p>
                <details class="more">
                    <summary>More</summary>
                    <p>Useful for debugging: it shows the exact order of dependencies leading to a failure.</p>
                </details>
            </div>
        </section>
    </main>
</div>
</body>
</html>

        <main class="content">
            <section class="hero">
                <h1>ResolutionEngine</h1>
                <p>The core logic for creating service instances.</p>
                <div class="meta">Foundation/Container/Features/Actions/Resolve/Engine.php</div>
            </section>

            <section class="section">
                <h2>Class Overview</h2>
                <div class="card">
                    <p>The Engine decides <em>how</em> to instantiate a service based on its definition or class
                        signature.</p>
                    <details class="more">
                        <summary>More</summary>
                        <p>While the <em>ResolutionPipeline</em> orchestrates the high-level flow (scope -> guard ->
                            resolve -> inject), the Engine is the worker that says: "This is a bound closure, I'll run
                            it" or "This is a concrete class, I'll ask the Instantiator to build it."</p>
                        <p>It also handles contextual bindings (when Service A asks for Service B, give it
                            Implementation B2).</p>
                    </details>
                </div>
            </section>

            <section class="section">
                <h2>Mechanism</h2>
                <div class="card">
                    <h3>Resolution Strategy</h3>
                    <ol>
                        <li><strong>Contextual Bindings:</strong> Checks if the parent service has a specific rule for
                            this dependency.</li>
                        <li><strong>Explicit Definitions:</strong> Looks up the global <em>DefinitionStore</em>.
                            <ul>
                                <li>If it's a <strong>Closure</strong>, execute it.</li>
                                <li>If it's an <strong>Object</strong>, return it directly.</li>
                                <li>If it's a <strong>String</strong> (alias), recursively resolve the alias.</li>
                            </ul>
                        </li>
                        <li><strong>Autowiring:</strong> If no definition exists, assume it's a class and try to
                            construct it.</li>
                    </ol>
                </div>
            </section>

            <section class="section">
                <h2>Methods</h2>

                <div class="card" id="resolve">
                    <h3>resolve</h3>
                    <p>Resolve the service requested in the context.</p>
                    <details class="more">
                        <summary>More</summary>
                        <p>The primary entry point used by <em>ResolveInstanceStep</em>.</p>
                    </details>
                </div>
            </section>
        </main>
    </div>
</body>

</html>
=== classes/Resolve/ResolutionPipeline.html ===
﻿<!doctype html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <meta charset="utf-8">
    <meta content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1" name="viewport">
    <title>ResolutionPipeline</title>
    <link href="../../styles.css" rel="stylesheet">
</head>
<body>
<div class="layout">
                    <aside class="sidebar">
        <div class="brand"><a href="../../index.html">Container Docs</a></div>
        <div class="search-container">
            <input type="text" class="search-input" placeholder="Search...">
        </div>
        <nav>
            <div class="nav-section">
                <h3 class="nav-title">Container (Root)</h3>
                <ul class="nav-list">
                    <li><a href="../Container.html">Container</a></li>
                </ul>
            </div>
            <div class="nav-section">
                <h3 class="nav-title">Act/Inject</h3>

    <main class="content">
        <section class="hero">
            <h1>ResolutionPipeline</h1>
            <p>Ordered pipeline that processes a resolution request step by step.</p>
            <div class="meta">Foundation/Container/Act/Resolve/ResolutionPipeline.php</div>
        </section>

        <section class="section">
            <h2>Class Overview</h2>
            <div class="card">
                <p>ResolutionPipeline is the fixed sequence of steps used to resolve a service. It ensures the same
                    order every time: scope check → binding lookup → autowire → finalize.</p>
                <details class="more">
                    <summary>More</summary>
                    <p>A pipeline is like an assembly line. Each pipe does one job and either returns a result or hands
                        the work to the next pipe.</p>
                </details>
            </div>
        </section>

        <section class="section">
            <h2>Methods</h2>

            <div class="card" id="__construct">
                <h3>__construct</h3>
                <p>Creates a pipeline with the default set of pipes.</p>
            </div>

            <div class="card" id="send">
                <h3>send</h3>
                <p>Sets the resolution context that will travel through the pipeline.</p>
                <details class="more">
                    <summary>More</summary>
                    <p>This is like placing a package on the conveyor belt so each station can work with it.</p>
                </details>
            </div>

            <div class="card" id="through">
                <h3>through</h3>
                <p>Overrides the list of pipes to be used for this run.</p>
            </div>

            <div class="card" id="thenReturn">
                <h3>thenReturn</h3>
                <p>Runs the pipeline and returns the resolved service.</p>
                <details class="more">
                    <summary>More</summary>
                    <p>This is the main execution point that walks through each pipe.</p>
                </details>
            </div>

            <div class="card" id="carry">
                <h3>carry</h3>
                <p>Creates the callable that chains the pipeline steps together.</p>
            </div>

            <div class="card" id="getPipeInstance">
                <h3>getPipeInstance</h3>
                <p>Instantiates or reuses a pipe class name into an object.</p>
            </div>
        </section>
    </main>
</div>
</body>
</html>

    <main class="content">
        <section class="hero">
            <h1>DefaultResolver</h1>
            <p>Uses a parameter's default value if no other strategy resolved it.</p>
            <div class="meta">Foundation/Container/Act/Resolve/Resolvers/DefaultResolver.php</div>
        </section>
        <section class="section">
            <h2>Class Overview</h2>
            <div class="card">
                <p>DefaultResolver checks whether the parameter defines a default value and returns it if available.</p>
                <details class="more">
                    <summary>More</summary>
                    <p>This keeps behavior consistent with PHP defaults and prevents unnecessary errors when defaults
                        are present.</p>
                </details>
            </div>
        </section>
    </main>
</div>
</body>
</html>

    <main class="content">
        <section class="hero">
            <h1>ExceptionResolver</h1>
            <p>Final resolver that throws a clear resolution error.</p>
            <div class="meta">Foundation/Container/Act/Resolve/Resolvers/ExceptionResolver.php</div>
        </section>
        <section class="section">
            <h2>Class Overview</h2>
            <div class="card">
                <p>ExceptionResolver is the last step. If no strategy succeeded, it throws a ResolutionException with
                    helpful context.</p>
                <details class="more">
                    <summary>More</summary>
                    <p>This makes failures loud and actionable. It includes the parameter name and the resolution path
                        so you can fix the missing binding.</p>
                </details>
            </div>
        </section>
    </main>
</div>
</body>
</html>

    <main class="content">
        <section class="hero">
            <h1>NullResolver</h1>
            <p>Returns null when the parameter allows null values.</p>
            <div class="meta">Foundation/Container/Act/Resolve/Resolvers/NullResolver.php</div>
        </section>
        <section class="section">
            <h2>Class Overview</h2>
            <div class="card">
                <p>NullResolver respects nullable parameters. If a parameter explicitly allows null, it returns null
                    instead of raising an error.</p>
                <details class="more">
                    <summary>More</summary>
                    <p>This keeps optional dependencies safe and avoids forcing the container to fabricate values where
                        none are required.</p>
                </details>
            </div>
        </section>
    </main>
</div>
</body>
</html>

    <main class="content">
        <section class="hero">
            <h1>OverrideResolver</h1>
            <p>First resolver that checks explicit parameter overrides.</p>
            <div class="meta">Foundation/Container/Act/Resolve/Resolvers/OverrideResolver.php</div>
        </section>
        <section class="section">
            <h2>Class Overview</h2>
            <div class="card">
                <p>OverrideResolver checks if the caller provided an explicit value for a parameter. If present, it
                    returns it immediately.</p>
                <details class="more">
                    <summary>More</summary>
                    <p>This gives manual control: you can override one dependency for a specific call without changing
                        the container's global rules.</p>
                </details>
            </div>
        </section>
    </main>
</div>
</body>
</html>

    <main class="content">
        <section class="hero">
            <h1>ParameterResolutionChain</h1>
            <p>Legacy fluent API for resolving parameters.</p>
            <div class="meta">Foundation/Container/Act/Resolve/Resolvers/ParameterResolutionChain.php</div>
        </section>
        <section class="section">
            <h2>Class Overview</h2>
            <div class="card">
                <p>This class provides a fluent DSL for parameter resolution. It remains for compatibility but the
                    engine now prefers the direct resolver sequence used by DependencyResolver.</p>
                <details class="more">
                    <summary>More</summary>
                    <p>If you are writing new code, prefer the container's normal resolution flow instead of calling
                        this DSL directly.</p>
                </details>
            </div>
        </section>
    </main>
</div>
</body>
</html>



=== classes/Resolve/Resolvers/ParameterResolver.html ===

    <main class="content">
        <section class="hero">
            <h1>ParameterResolver</h1>
            <p>Base class for parameter resolution steps.</p>
            <div class="meta">Foundation/Container/Act/Resolve/Resolvers/ParameterResolver.php</div>
        </section>

        <section class="section">
            <h2>Class Overview</h2>
            <div class="card">
                <p>ParameterResolver is the abstract base for resolving a single argument. Concrete resolvers handle
                    overrides, type hints, defaults, nullable fallback, or final errors.</p>
                <details class="more">
                    <summary>More</summary>
                    <p>Think of these resolvers as a checklist. Each step tries one strategy. If it does not work, the
                        next step is tried. This keeps logic clear and predictable.</p>
                </details>
            </div>
        </section>

        <section class="section">
            <h2>Methods</h2>
            <div class="card" id="next">
                <h3>next</h3>
                <p>Links another resolver as the next step in the sequence.</p>
            </div>
            <div class="card" id="resolve">
                <h3>resolve</h3>
                <p>Attempts resolution via this step, then delegates to the next if unresolved.</p>
            </div>
            <div class="card" id="attemptResolve">
                <h3>attemptResolve</h3>
                <p>Concrete strategy for this resolver.</p>
            </div>
            <div class="card" id="unresolved">
                <h3>unresolved</h3>
                <p>Returns a sentinel used to indicate “not resolved”.</p>
            </div>
        </section>
    </main>
</div>
</body>
</html>

    <main class="content">
        <section class="hero">
            <h1>TypeResolver</h1>
            <p>Resolves a parameter based on its class/interface type hint.</p>
            <div class="meta">Foundation/Container/Act/Resolve/Resolvers/TypeResolver.php</div>
        </section>
        <section class="section">
            <h2>Class Overview</h2>
            <div class="card">
                <p>TypeResolver asks the container to resolve the type-hinted class or interface. This is the most
                    common path for automatic dependency injection.</p>
                <details class="more">
                    <summary>More</summary>
                    <p>If a parameter is typed as <span class="code">UserRepositoryInterface</span>, this resolver asks
                        the container to build whatever concrete class is bound to that interface.</p>
                </details>
            </div>
        </section>
    </main>
</div>
</body>
</html>

        <main class="content">
            <section class="hero">
                <h1>PrototypeAnalyzer</h1>
                <p>Performs deep reflection analysis to build service blueprints.</p>
                <div class="meta">Foundation/Container/Features/Think/Analyze/PrototypeAnalyzer.php</div>
            </section>

            <section class="section">
                <h2>Class Overview</h2>
                <div class="card">
                    <p>This class is the "brain" of the container's build phase. It inspects a class using PHP
                        Reflection and produces a <a href="../Model/ServicePrototype.html">ServicePrototype</a>.</p>
                    <details class="more">
                        <summary>More</summary>
                        <p>It scans for:</p>
                        <ul>
                            <li>Constructor signatures and type hints.</li>
                            <li>Properties marked with <code>#[Inject]</code>.</li>
                            <li>Methods marked with <code>#[Inject]</code>.</li>
                        </ul>
                        <p>It delegates low-level type resolution to <a
                                href="ReflectionTypeAnalyzer.html">ReflectionTypeAnalyzer</a>.</p>
                    </details>
                </div>
            </section>

            <section class="section">
                <h2>Story Example</h2>
                <div class="card">
                    <h3>Scenario: Analyzing a UserService</h3>
                    <p>When the container needs to resolve <code>UserService</code>, it first analyzes its structure:
                    </p>
                    <pre><code class="language-php">class UserService
{
    public function __construct(
        private UserRepository $repo,
        private Logger $logger
    ) {}
    
    #[Inject]
    private CacheInterface $cache;
    
    #[Inject]
    public function setEventDispatcher(EventDispatcher $events): void
    {
        $this->events = $events;
    }
}</code></pre>
                    <details class="more">
                        <summary>Analysis Process</summary>
                        <ol>
                            <li><strong>Reflect Class:</strong> <a
                                    href="ReflectionTypeAnalyzer.html">ReflectionTypeAnalyzer</a> creates
                                <code>ReflectionClass</code> for <code>UserService</code>.</li>
                            <li><strong>Analyze Constructor:</strong> Finds 2 parameters (<code>UserRepository</code>,
                                <code>Logger</code>).</li>
                            <li><strong>Analyze Properties:</strong> Finds <code>$cache</code> with
                                <code>#[Inject]</code> attribute.</li>
                            <li><strong>Analyze Methods:</strong> Finds <code>setEventDispatcher()</code> with
                                <code>#[Inject]</code>.</li>
                            <li><strong>Build Prototype:</strong> Creates <a
                                    href="../Model/ServicePrototype.html">ServicePrototype</a> with all injection
                                points.</li>
                            <li><strong>Cache:</strong> <a
                                    href="../Cache/FilePrototypeCache.html">FilePrototypeCache</a> stores the prototype
                                for reuse.</li>
                        </ol>
                        <p><strong>Result:</strong> The container now knows exactly how to build
                            <code>UserService</code> without re-analyzing it.</p>
                        <p><strong>Related:</strong> <a
                                href="../Prototype/ServicePrototypeFactory.html">ServicePrototypeFactory</a>, <a
                                href="../Verify/VerifyPrototype.html">VerifyPrototype</a></p>
                    </details>
                </div>
            </section>
        </main>
    </div>
</body>

</html>
=== classes/Think/Analyze/ReflectionTypeAnalyzer.html ===

        <main class="content">
            <section class="hero">
                <h1>ReflectionTypeAnalyzer</h1>
                <p>Low-level reflection and type resolution utilities.</p>
                <div class="meta">Foundation/Container/Features/Think/Analyze/ReflectionTypeAnalyzer.php</div>
            </section>

            <section class="section">
                <h2>Class Overview</h2>
                <div class="card">
                    <p>Provides a cached access layer to PHP's Reflection API, optimized for repetitive lookups.</p>
                    <details class="more">
                        <summary>More</summary>
                        <p>It handles the complexities of resolving union types, intersection types, and checking for
                            attribute existence. It ensures that expensive reflection objects (like
                            <em>ReflectionClass</em>) are reused.</p>
                    </details>
                </div>
            </section>
        </main>
    </div>
</body>

</html>

        <main class="content">
            <section class="hero">
                <h1>FilePrototypeCache</h1>
                <p>Persists analyzed service prototypes to disk for performance.</p>
                <div class="meta">Foundation/Container/Features/Think/Cache/FilePrototypeCache.php</div>
            </section>

            <section class="section">
                <h2>Class Overview</h2>
                <div class="card">
                    <p>Stores <em>ServicePrototype</em> objects as PHP files using <code>var_export</code>. This allows
                        for extremely fast loading via OpCache.</p>
                    <details class="more">
                        <summary>More</summary>
                        <p>It implements atomic writes to prevent race conditions during cache generation. Used to avoid
                            re-analyzing classes on every request in production.</p>
                    </details>
                </div>
            </section>
        </main>
    </div>
</body>

</html>
=== classes/Think/Model/MethodPrototype.html ===
<!doctype html>
<html lang="en">

<head>
    <meta charset="utf-8">
    <meta content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1" name="viewport">
    <title>MethodPrototype</title>
    <link href="../../../styles.css" rel="stylesheet">
</head>

<body>
    <div class="layout">
                        <aside class="sidebar">
        <div class="brand"><a href="../../../index.html">Container Docs</a></div>
        <div class="search-container">
            <input type="text" class="search-input" placeholder="Search...">
        </div>
        <nav>
            <div class="nav-section">
                <h3 class="nav-title">Container (Root)</h3>
                <ul class="nav-list">
                    <li><a href="../../Container.html">Container</a></li>
                </ul>
            </div>
            <div class="nav-section">
                <h3 class="nav-title">Act/Inject</h3>
                <ul class="nav-list">
                    <li><a href="../../Act/Inject/InjectDependencies.html">InjectDependencies</a></li>
                    <li><a href="../../Act/Inject/PropertyInjector.html">PropertyInjector</a></li>
                </ul>

        <main class="content">
            <section class="hero">
                <h1>MethodPrototype</h1>
                <p>Blueprint for method-based dependency injection.</p>
                <div class="meta">Foundation/Container/Features/Think/Model/MethodPrototype.php</div>
            </section>

            <section class="section">
                <h2>Class Overview</h2>
                <div class="card">
                    <p>Immutable model representing a method that requires dependency injection (constructor or setter).
                    </p>
                    <details class="more">
                        <summary>More</summary>
                        <p>Contains:</p>
                        <ul>
                            <li><strong>name:</strong> Method name (e.g., '__construct', 'setLogger').</li>
                            <li><strong>parameters:</strong> Array of <em>ParameterPrototype</em> objects.</li>
                        </ul>
                        <p>Used during runtime to know which parameters to resolve and inject when calling the method.
                        </p>
                    </details>
                </div>
            </section>
        </main>
    </div>
</body>

</html>
=== classes/Think/Model/ParameterPrototype.html ===

        <main class="content">
            <section class="hero">
                <h1>ParameterPrototype</h1>
                <p>Specification for method parameter dependency resolution.</p>
                <div class="meta">Foundation/Container/Features/Think/Model/ParameterPrototype.php</div>
            </section>

            <section class="section">
                <h2>Class Overview</h2>
                <div class="card">
                    <p>Immutable model describing a single method parameter and how to resolve it.</p>
                    <details class="more">
                        <summary>More</summary>
                        <p>Properties:</p>
                        <ul>
                            <li><strong>name:</strong> Parameter name.</li>
                            <li><strong>type:</strong> Type hint (class/interface for DI).</li>
                            <li><strong>hasDefault:</strong> Whether parameter has default value.</li>
                            <li><strong>default:</strong> The default value.</li>
                            <li><strong>isVariadic:</strong> Whether it's a variadic parameter (...$args).</li>
                            <li><strong>allowsNull:</strong> Whether null is acceptable.</li>
                            <li><strong>required:</strong> Whether resolution must succeed.</li>
                        </ul>
                        <p>Used by <em>DependencyResolver</em> to determine how to provide values for each parameter.
                        </p>
                    </details>
                </div>
            </section>
        </main>
    </div>
</body>

</html>
=== classes/Think/Model/PropertyPrototype.html ===

                    <li><a href="../../Resolve/Resolvers/ParameterResolutionChain.html">ParameterResolutionChain</a></li>
                    <li><a href="../../Resolve/Resolvers/ParameterResolver.html">ParameterResolver</a></li>
                    <li><a href="../../Resolve/Resolvers/TypeResolver.html">TypeResolver</a></li>
                </ul>
            </div>

                    <li><a href="ServicePrototype.html">ServicePrototype</a></li>
                </ul>

        </nav>

    <main class="content">
        <section class="hero">
            <h1>PropertyPrototype</h1>
            <p>Immutable blueprint for property injection.</p>
            <div class="meta">Foundation/Container/Think/Model/PropertyPrototype.php</div>
        </section>

        <section class="section">
            <h2>Class Overview</h2>
            <div class="card">
                <p>PropertyPrototype stores the analysis metadata needed to inject a single property.</p>
                <details class="more">
                    <summary>More</summary>
                    <p>This object is produced during the Think phase and then reused at runtime. It captures the
                        property name, type hint (if any), default value presence, and nullability.</p>
                    <p>Because it is immutable, it can be cached and safely reused across requests. That is the entire
                        point of the Think phase: pay reflection cost once, then reuse the result.</p>
                </details>
            </div>
        </section>
    </main>
</div>
</body>
</html>

        <main class="content">
            <section class="hero">
                <h1>ServicePrototype</h1>
                <p>Immutable blueprint of a class's dependency structure.</p>
                <div class="meta">Foundation/Container/Features/Think/Model/ServicePrototype.php</div>
            </section>

            <section class="section">
                <h2>Class Overview</h2>
                <div class="card">
                    <p>A DTO containing everything the container needs to know to instantiate a class.</p>
                    <details class="more">
                        <summary>More</summary>
                        <p>It captures:</p>
                        <ul>
                            <li><strong>Constructor:</strong> Parameters and types.</li>
                            <li><strong>Injected Properties:</strong> Properties with <code>#[Inject]</code>.</li>
                            <li><strong>Injected Methods:</strong> Methods with <code>#[Inject]</code>.</li>
                        </ul>
                        <p>Designed to be serializable for caching.</p>
                    </details>
                </div>
            </section>
        </main>
    </div>
</body>

</html>

        <main class="content">
            <section class="hero">
                <h1>ServicePrototypeFactoryInterface</h1>
                <p>Contract for prototype factory implementations.</p>
                <div class="meta">
                    Foundation/Container/Features/Think/Prototype/Contracts/ServicePrototypeFactoryInterface.php</div>
            </section>

            <section class="section">
                <h2>Interface Overview</h2>
                <div class="card">
                    <p>Defines the contract for creating and managing service prototypes.</p>
                    <details class="more">
                        <summary>More</summary>
                        <p>Key methods:</p>
                        <ul>
                            <li><strong>createFor($class):</strong> Create/retrieve prototype for a class.</li>
                            <li><strong>hasPrototype($class):</strong> Check if prototype exists in cache.</li>
                            <li><strong>getAnalyzer():</strong> Access the underlying analyzer.</li>
                        </ul>
                        <p>Implemented by <em>ServicePrototypeFactory</em>.</p>
                    </details>
                </div>
            </section>
        </main>
    </div>
</body>

</html>
=== classes/Think/Prototype/ServicePrototypeFactory.html ===

        <main class="content">
            <section class="hero">
                <h1>ServicePrototypeFactory</h1>
                <p>The facade for obtaining ServicePrototypes, handling caching automatically.</p>
                <div class="meta">Foundation/Container/Features/Think/Prototype/ServicePrototypeFactory.php</div>
            </section>

            <section class="section">
                <h2>Class Overview</h2>
                <div class="card">
                    <p>Coordiantes the Cache and the Analyzer to provide blueprints efficiently.</p>
                    <details class="more">
                        <summary>More</summary>
                        <p>When requested for a class:</p>
                        <ol>
                            <li>Checks the <em>PrototypeCache</em>.</li>
                            <li>If missing, calls <em>PrototypeAnalyzer</em> to generate it.</li>
                            <li>Saves the new prototype to the cache.</li>
                            <li>Returns the prototype.</li>
                        </ol>
                    </details>
                </div>
            </section>
        </main>
    </div>
</body>

</html>
=== classes/Think/Verify/VerifyPrototype.html ===

        <main class="content">
            <section class="hero">
                <h1>VerifyPrototype</h1>
                <p>Validates prototypes for correctness and safety.</p>
                <div class="meta">Foundation/Container/Features/Think/Verify/VerifyPrototype.php</div>
            </section>

            <section class="section">
                <h2>Class Overview</h2>
                <div class="card">
                    <p>Ensures that a <em>ServicePrototype</em> is valid before it is used or cached.</p>
                    <details class="more">
                        <summary>More</summary>
                        <p>Checks include:</p>
                        <ul>
                            <li>Ensuring the class is instantiable.</li>
                            <li>Verifying that all injected parameters have resolveable types.</li>
                            <li>Detecting obvious configuration errors.</li>
                        </ul>
                    </details>
                </div>
            </section>
        </main>
    </div>
</body>

</html>
=== editor-demo.html ===

        .edit-mode { border: 2px dashed #007bff; padding: 10px; background: #f8f9ff; }
        .edit-controls { margin: 10px 0; padding: 10px; background: #e9ecef; border-radius: 4px; }

    <main class="content">
        <div class="hero">
            <h1>CKEditor Integration Demo</h1>
            <p>Demonstration of inline documentation editing with CKEditor</p>
            <div class="meta">
                <strong>Demo Page</strong><br>
                <strong>Generated:</strong> 2026-01-09
            </div>
        </div>

        <div class="edit-controls">
            <strong>Demo Controls:</strong>
            <button onclick="enableAllEditors()">Enable All Editors</button>
            <button onclick="showInstructions()">Show Instructions</button>
            <span style="margin-left: 20px; color: #666;">
                Click "Edit" on any section below to start editing with CKEditor
            </span>
        </div>

        <section class="section content-card">
            <h2>Getting Started</h2>
            <div class="card">
                <p>This demo shows how CKEditor can be integrated into your documentation for manual content editing.</p>
                <p>The editor provides rich text editing capabilities including:</p>
                <ul>
                    <li>Bold and italic text formatting</li>
                    <li>Headings and lists</li>
                    <li>Code blocks with syntax highlighting</li>
                    <li>Links and tables</li>
                    <li>Undo/redo functionality</li>
                </ul>
            </div>
        </section>

        <section class="section content-card">
            <h2>Technical Implementation</h2>
            <div class="card">
                <p>The integration works by:</p>
                <ol>
                    <li>Loading CKEditor from CDN</li>
                    <li>Adding edit buttons to content sections</li>
                    <li>Initializing editors on demand</li>
                    <li>Providing save functionality (demo only)</li>
                </ol>
                <p><strong>Key Features:</strong></p>
                <ul>
                    <li>Inline editing without page reload</li>
                    <li>Multiple editors per page</li>
                    <li>Code syntax highlighting support</li>
                    <li>Responsive design compatibility</li>
                </ul>
            </div>
        </section>

        <section class="section content-card">
            <h2>Code Example</h2>
            <div class="card">
                <p>Here's how you would integrate CKEditor into your documentation:</p>
                <pre><code class="language-javascript">// Initialize CKEditor on a content area
const editor = await ClassicEditor.create(element, {
    toolbar: ['heading', 'bold', 'italic', 'link', 'codeBlock'],
    codeBlock: {
        languages: [
            { language: 'php', label: 'PHP' },
            { language: 'javascript', label: 'JavaScript' }
        ]
    }
});

// Get edited content
const content = editor.getData();</code></pre>
            </div>
        </section>

        <section class="section content-card">
            <h2>Next Steps</h2>
            <div class="card">
                <p>To fully implement this for your documentation:</p>
                <ol>
                    <li><strong>Add Backend Saving:</strong> Create PHP endpoints to save content</li>
                    <li><strong>Authentication:</strong> Add user authentication and permissions</li>
                    <li><strong>Version Control:</strong> Track changes and provide rollback</li>
                    <li><strong>Preview System:</strong> Allow preview before publishing</li>
                    <li><strong>Regeneration:</strong> Update docs.txt and regenerate HTML</li>
                </ol>
            </div>
        </section>
    </main>
</div>

<script>
// Demo-specific functionality
let demoEditors = new Map();

function enableAllEditors() {
    const sections = document.querySelectorAll('.section');
    sections.forEach((section, index) => {
        const editBtn = section.querySelector('button');
        if (editBtn && editBtn.textContent === 'Edit') {
            editBtn.click();
        }
    });
}

function showInstructions() {
    alert(`CKEditor Demo Instructions:

1. Click "Edit" on any section to enable CKEditor
2. Use the toolbar to format text, add lists, code blocks, etc.
3. Click "Save" to see the save dialog (demo only)
4. Changes are shown in the browser console

This demonstrates how your documentation can be edited inline with a rich text editor.`);
}

// CKEditor integration (simplified for demo)
class DemoEditor {
    constructor() {
        this.editors = new Map();
        this.init();
    }

    init() {
        this.makeContentEditable();
    }

    makeContentEditable() {
        const sections = document.querySelectorAll('.section');
        sections.forEach((section, index) => {
            section.style.position = 'relative';

            if (!section.querySelector('button')) {
                const editBtn = document.createElement('button');
                editBtn.textContent = 'Edit';
                editBtn.style.position = 'absolute';
                editBtn.style.top = '10px';
                editBtn.style.right = '10px';
                editBtn.style.zIndex = '1000';
                editBtn.onclick = () => this.enableCKEditor(section, index);
                section.appendChild(editBtn);
            }

            section.classList.add('edit-mode');
        });
    }

    async enableCKEditor(section, index) {
        if (this.editors.has(index)) {
            return;
        }

        // Find the editable content area
        let content = section.querySelector('.card');
        if (!content) {
            content = section;
        }

        // Create a temporary editable div if needed
        if (!content.id) {
            content.id = `editor-${index}`;
        }

        try {
            console.log('Initializing CKEditor on:', content);

            const editor = await ClassicEditor.create(content, {
                toolbar: [
                    'heading', '|',
                    'bold', 'italic', 'link', '|',
                    'bulletedList', 'numberedList', 'blockQuote', '|',
                    'codeBlock', 'insertTable', '|',
                    'undo', 'redo'
                ],
                codeBlock: {
                    languages: [
                        { language: 'php', label: 'PHP' },
                        { language: 'javascript', label: 'JavaScript' },
                        { language: 'html', label: 'HTML' },
                        { language: 'css', label: 'CSS' }
                    ]
                },
                // Add some basic configuration
                placeholder: 'Start editing...',
                language: 'en'
            });

            this.editors.set(index, { editor, section, originalContent: content.innerHTML });

            const editBtn = section.querySelector('button');
            if (editBtn) {
                editBtn.textContent = 'Save';
                editBtn.onclick = () => this.saveSection(index);
            }

            console.log('CKEditor initialized successfully');

        } catch (error) {
            console.error('Failed to initialize CKEditor:', error);

            // Try fallback initialization
            try {
                console.log('Trying fallback initialization...');
                const editor = await ClassicEditor.create(`#${content.id}`, {
                    toolbar: ['bold', 'italic', 'link', 'bulletedList', 'numberedList']
                });
                this.editors.set(index, { editor, section, originalContent: content.innerHTML });
                console.log('Fallback CKEditor initialized successfully');
            } catch (fallbackError) {
                console.error('Fallback also failed:', fallbackError);
                alert('Failed to initialize editor. Please check console for details.');
            }
        }
    }

    saveSection(index) {
        const editorData = this.editors.get(index);
        if (editorData) {
            const content = editorData.editor.getData();
            console.log('Demo: Section content to save:', content);

            // Show demo save dialog
            this.showDemoSaveDialog(content, index);
        }
    }

    showDemoSaveDialog(content, identifier) {
        const overlay = document.createElement('div');
        overlay.style.cssText = `
            position: fixed; top: 0; left: 0; right: 0; bottom: 0;
            background: rgba(0,0,0,0.5); z-index: 10000;
            display: flex; align-items: center; justify-content: center;
        `;

        overlay.innerHTML = `
            <div style="background: white; padding: 20px; border-radius: 8px; max-width: 700px; width: 90%;">
                <h3>Demo Save Dialog</h3>
                <p><strong>This is a demonstration.</strong> In a real implementation, this content would be saved to your documentation source.</p>
                <div style="margin: 20px 0;">
                    <strong>Edited Content (first 500 characters):</strong><br>
                    <textarea style="width: 100%; height: 200px; margin-top: 10px; font-family: monospace;" readonly>${content.replace(/<[^>]*>/g, '').substring(0, 500)}${content.length > 500 ? '...' : ''}</textarea>
                </div>
                <div style="margin-top: 20px; padding-top: 20px; border-top: 1px solid #dee2e6;">
                    <p><strong>To implement real saving:</strong></p>
                    <ul>
                        <li>Create a PHP API endpoint (POST /api/docs/save)</li>
                        <li>Send content as JSON to the server</li>
                        <li>Update docs.txt or source files</li>
                        <li>Regenerate documentation HTML</li>
                        <li>Add authentication and validation</li>
                    </ul>
                </div>
                <div style="text-align: right; margin-top: 20px;">
                    <button onclick="this.closest('div').parentElement.remove()">Close Demo</button>
                </div>
            </div>
        `;

        document.body.appendChild(overlay);
    }
}

// Initialize demo
document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', () => {
    new DemoEditor();
});
</script>

</body>
</html>

    <main class="content">
        <div class="hero">
            <h1>Foundation Container</h1>
            <p>A comprehensive dependency injection container that makes managing object dependencies simple and reliable.</p>
            <div class="meta">
                <strong>File Path:</strong> /<br>
                <strong>Folder Context:</strong> Root of the Container component<br>
                <strong>Generated:</strong> 2026-01-08
            </div>
        </div>

        <section id="quick-summary" class="section content-card">
            <h2>Quick Summary</h2>
            <p>The Foundation Container is your application's personal assistant for managing dependencies. When your code needs a tool, database connection, or service, you just ask the container, and it provides a fully configured instance. This eliminates the tedious work of manually creating and connecting objects, letting you focus on what your application actually does rather than how it's wired together.</p>
            <p>This component exists because manual dependency management leads to tightly coupled code that's hard to test, maintain, and extend. By centralizing object creation and wiring, the container makes your codebase more modular, testable, and flexible.</p>
        </section>

        <section id="terminology" class="section content-card">
            <h2>Terminology</h2>
            <dl>
                <dt>Dependency Injection (DI)</dt>
                <dd>The practice of providing objects with their dependencies rather than having them create dependencies themselves. Instead of a class creating its own database connection, the connection is "injected" from outside.</dd>
                <dt>Container</dt>
                <dd>A registry that knows how to create and configure objects. When you ask for a "UserService", the container builds it with all its required dependencies.</dd>
                <dt>Service</dt>
                <dd>Any object that the container can create and manage. This could be a database connection, email sender, or business logic class.</dd>
                <dt>Binding</dt>
                <dd>A rule that tells the container how to create a specific service. For example: "when asked for LoggerInterface, create a FileLogger instance".</dd>
                <dt>Autowiring</dt>
                <dd>The container automatically figuring out what dependencies a class needs by looking at its constructor parameters.</dd>
                <dt>Scope</dt>
                <dd>How long a service instance lives. Singleton scope means one instance for the whole application, scoped means one per request, transient means new instance each time.</dd>
                <dt>Resolution</dt>
                <dd>The process of turning a service name into an actual object instance, including all its dependencies.</dd>
                <dt>Constructor Injection</dt>
                <dd>Passing dependencies through a class's constructor, like <code>new UserService($database, $logger)</code>.</dd>
                <dt>Property Injection</dt>
                <dd>Setting dependencies directly on object properties after construction, often using attributes like #[Inject].</dd>
                <dt>Method Injection</dt>
                <dd>Calling methods on an object to provide dependencies, like <code>$object->setLogger($logger)</code>.</dd>
            </dl>
        </section>

        <section id="think-of-it" class="section content-card">
            <h2>Think of It Like...</h2>
            <p>Imagine you're running a busy restaurant kitchen. Each station (pasta, grill, dessert) needs specific tools and ingredients to do their job. Instead of each cook running to the store every time they need something, you have a professional kitchen system where:</p>
            <ul>
                <li>The pantry (container) stores all ingredients and tools</li>
                <li>Cooks ask the expediter (container interface) for what they need</li>
                <li>The expediter coordinates with storage and prep to provide exactly what's required</li>
                <li>Everything is prepared fresh or retrieved from storage as needed</li>
            </ul>
            <div class="table-wrapper">
                <table>
                    <thead>
                        <tr>
                            <th>Restaurant Kitchen</th>
                            <th>Dependency Injection Container</th>
                        </tr>
                    </thead>
                    <tbody>
                        <tr>
                            <td>Cook asking for ingredients</td>
                            <td>Class requesting dependencies</td>
                        </tr>
                        <tr>
                            <td>Pantry storing food/supplies</td>
                            <td>Container storing service definitions</td>
                        </tr>
                        <tr>
                            <td>Expediter coordinating orders</td>
                            <td>Container coordinating object creation</td>
                        </tr>
                        <tr>
                            <td>Prep cook preparing ingredients</td>
                            <td>Autowiring resolving dependencies</td>
                        </tr>
                        <tr>
                            <td>Refrigerated storage for perishables</td>
                            <td>Scoped storage for request-bound services</td>
                        </tr>
                    </tbody>
                </table>
            </div>
        </section>

        <section id="story-example" class="section content-card">
            <h2>Story Example</h2>
            <p>Let's say you're building an e-commerce website. You have a <code>OrderProcessor</code> that needs to:</p>
            <ul>
                <li>Check inventory in the database</li>
                <li>Process payment through a gateway</li>
                <li>Send confirmation emails</li>
                <li>Log the transaction</li>
            </ul>
            <h3>The Problem Before DI</h3>
            <pre><code class="language-php">class OrderProcessor {
    public function process(Order $order) {
        // Manual dependency management - messy!
        $db = new DatabaseConnection('localhost', 'user', 'pass');
        $inventory = new InventoryService($db);
        
        if (!$inventory->checkStock($order)) {
            throw new Exception('Out of stock');
        }
        
        $payment = new StripeGateway('sk_test_...');
        $result = $payment->charge($order->total);
        
        $email = new SmtpMailer('smtp.gmail.com', 587, 'user@gmail.com');
        $email->send($order->email, 'Order Confirmed', '...');
        
        $logger = new FileLogger('/var/log/app.log');
        $logger->info("Order {$order->id} processed");
    }
}</code></pre>
            <h3>The Solution With Container</h3>
            <pre><code class="language-php">// In your bootstrap
$container->bind(InventoryInterface::class, SqlInventory::class);
$container->singleton(PaymentGateway::class, StripeGateway::class);
$container->bind(MailerInterface::class, SmtpMailer::class);
$container->singleton(LoggerInterface::class, FileLogger::class);

class OrderProcessor {
    public function __construct(
        private InventoryInterface $inventory,
        private PaymentGateway $payment,
        private MailerInterface $mailer,
        private LoggerInterface $logger
    ) {}
    
    public function process(Order $order) {
        if (!$this->inventory->checkStock($order)) {
            throw new Exception('Out of stock');
        }
        
        $result = $this->payment->charge($order->total);
        $this->mailer->send($order->email, 'Order Confirmed', '...');
        $this->logger->info("Order {$order->id} processed");
    }
}

// Usage
$processor = $container->get(OrderProcessor::class);
$processor->process($order);</code></pre>
            <p>Now your code is clean, testable, and flexible. You can easily swap payment providers, use different email services for testing, or change logging destinations without touching the business logic.</p>
        </section>

        <section id="for-dummies" class="section content-card">
            <h2>For Dummies</h2>
            <p>Dependency injection is like having a magic assistant who knows what you need before you ask. Instead of you hunting around your house for a screwdriver, hammer, and nails every time you want to hang a picture, your assistant appears with exactly the right tools, already organized and ready to use.</p>
            <h3>What Problem Does This Solve?</h3>
            <p>Without a container, every class has to know how to create its own dependencies. This leads to code like:</p>
            <pre><code class="language-php">class UserService {
    public function __construct() {
        $this->db = new Database();
        $this->logger = new FileLogger('/var/log/app.log');
        $this->cache = new RedisCache('localhost:6379');
    }
}</code></pre>
            <p>This is bad because:</p>
            <ul>
                <li>Hard to test (can't use fake database for tests)</li>
                <li>Hard to change (want to use different logger? Change everywhere)</li>
                <li>Tightly coupled (UserService is stuck with specific implementations)</li>
                <li>Configuration scattered throughout the code</li>
            </ul>
            <h3>How It Works (Simple Mental Model)</h3>
            <ol>
                <li>You tell the container: "When someone asks for DatabaseInterface, give them PostgresDatabase"</li>
                <li>Your classes say: "I need a DatabaseInterface" in their constructor</li>
                <li>When you ask the container for UserService, it reads the constructor and automatically provides the PostgresDatabase</li>
                <li>You get a fully wired UserService without knowing how it was assembled</li>
            </ol>
            <h3>Common Mistakes & Misconceptions</h3>
            <ul>
                <li><strong>Mistake:</strong> Using <code>$container->get()</code> inside classes instead of constructor injection</li>
                <li><strong>Why it's wrong:</strong> Makes classes hard to test and creates hidden dependencies</li>
                <li><strong>Fix:</strong> Always use constructor parameters for dependencies</li>
            </ul>
            <ul>
                <li><strong>Mistake:</strong> Making everything a singleton</li>
                <li><strong>Why it's wrong:</strong> Can cause state pollution between requests</li>
                <li><strong>Fix:</strong> Use scoped lifetime for request-specific data</li>
            </ul>
            <ul>
                <li><strong>Misconception:</strong> DI is only for big applications</li>
                <li><strong>Reality:</strong> Even small apps benefit from testable, maintainable code</li>
            </ul>
            <h3>FAQ</h3>
            <dl>
                <dt>Do I need to register every class?</dt>
                <dd>No! The container can automatically create concrete classes through autowiring. You only need bindings when you want to use interfaces or control which implementation to use.</dd>
                <dt>What's the difference between singleton and scoped?</dt>
                <dd>Singleton means one instance for the entire application. Scoped means one instance per "scope" (usually per web request). Use scoped for things that shouldn't be shared between users.</dd>
                <dt>How do I test classes that use the container?</dt>
                <dd>Don't inject the container - inject the specific services. Then in tests, you can pass mock objects directly to the constructor.</dd>
                <dt>Is this the same as a service locator?</dt>
                <dd>No. Service locator is an anti-pattern where classes ask for dependencies. DI pushes dependencies in through constructors, keeping classes clean and testable.</dd>
            </dl>
        </section>

        <section id="how-it-works" class="section content-card">
            <h2>How It Works (Technical)</h2>
            <p>The container uses a multi-phase process to resolve services:</p>
            <h3>Phase 1: Registration</h3>
            <ul>
                <li>Bindings are stored in DefinitionStore</li>
                <li>Prototypes are pre-computed for performance</li>
                <li>Reflection analyzes constructor signatures</li>
            </ul>
            <h3>Phase 2: Resolution Pipeline</h3>
            <ol>
                <li><strong>Scope Check:</strong> Fast lookup for existing instances</li>
                <li><strong>Binding Lookup:</strong> Find explicit service definitions</li>
                <li><strong>Autowiring Fallback:</strong> Analyze constructor for concrete classes</li>
                <li><strong>Recursive Resolution:</strong> Resolve all dependencies</li>
                <li><strong>Lifecycle Management:</strong> Cache according to scope rules</li>
                <li><strong>Injection:</strong> Apply property/method injection if configured</li>
            </ol>
            <h3>Key Patterns Used</h3>
            <ul>
                <li><strong>Factory Pattern:</strong> Container acts as a factory for object creation</li>
                <li><strong>Registry Pattern:</strong> Central storage of service definitions</li>
                <li><strong>Pipeline Pattern:</strong> Modular resolution steps</li>
                <li><strong>Strategy Pattern:</strong> Pluggable lifecycle strategies</li>
            </ul>
            <h3>Performance Optimizations</h3>
            <ul>
                <li>Prototype caching avoids repeated reflection</li>
                <li>Scope caches prevent unnecessary recreation</li>
                <li>Lazy loading defers expensive operations</li>
                <li>Compiled definitions for production deployment</li>
            </ul>
        </section>

        <section id="architecture-role" class="section content-card">
            <h2>Architecture Role</h2>
            <p>This is the root component of the entire dependency injection system. It sits at the foundation of your application architecture, providing the infrastructure that enables loosely coupled, testable code.</p>
            <h3>What Depends on This Component</h3>
            <ul>
                <li>All application services and business logic</li>
                <li>Web frameworks and HTTP request handling</li>
                <li>Data access layers and repositories</li>
                <li>External integrations and APIs</li>
                <li>Background jobs and queue processors</li>
            </ul>
            <h3>What This Component Depends On</h3>
            <ul>
                <li>PHP reflection system for class analysis</li>
                <li>File system for configuration and caching</li>
                <li>PSR standards for interoperability</li>
                <li>Optional: external configuration formats (YAML, etc.)</li>
            </ul>
            <h3>How It Fits Into the Larger System</h3>
            <p>The container acts as the composition root - the single place where your application's object graph is assembled. This inversion of control means:</p>
            <ul>
                <li>Application code focuses on behavior, not assembly</li>
                <li>Configuration is centralized and version controlled</li>
                <li>Testing becomes straightforward with dependency substitution</li>
                <li>Cross-cutting concerns (logging, security) can be applied uniformly</li>
            </ul>
        </section>

        <section id="risks-trade-offs" class="section content-card">
            <h2>Risks, Trade-offs & Recommended Practices</h2>
            <h3>Performance Considerations</h3>
            <p><strong>Risk:</strong> Container resolution can be slower than direct instantiation due to reflection and recursive dependency resolution.</p>
            <p><strong>Why it matters:</strong> High-traffic applications might experience latency if services are resolved frequently in hot paths.</p>
            <p><strong>Design stance:</strong> The container optimizes for maintainability over raw performance, using caching and compilation to mitigate costs.</p>
            <p><strong>Recommended practice:</strong> Use singleton scope for stateless services, enable compilation for production, and avoid container calls in tight loops.</p>
            <h3>Security Boundaries</h3>
            <p><strong>Risk:</strong> Malicious services could be registered if configuration is compromised.</p>
            <p><strong>Why it matters:</strong> Container controls object creation, so compromised bindings could lead to code execution vulnerabilities.</p>
            <p><strong>Design stance:</strong> The Guard component provides namespace whitelisting and policy enforcement.</p>
            <p><strong>Recommended practice:</strong> Always validate configuration sources, use namespace restrictions in production, and audit service registrations.</p>
            <h3>Memory Management</h3>
            <p><strong>Risk:</strong> Scoped instances not properly cleaned up can cause memory leaks in long-running applications.</p>
            <p><strong>Why it matters:</strong> Web applications serving many requests could accumulate garbage if scopes aren't managed.</p>
            <p><strong>Design stance:</strong> Scope lifecycle is explicit with beginScope()/endScope() to ensure cleanup.</p>
            <p><strong>Recommended practice:</strong> Always use try/finally blocks around scoped operations, monitor memory usage, and implement proper disposal patterns.</p>
            <h3>Testing Complexity</h3>
            <p><strong>Risk:</strong> Over-reliance on global container state makes integration tests brittle.</p>
            <p><strong>Why it matters:</strong> Tests that depend on global container configuration can interfere with each other.</p>
            <p><strong>Design stance:</strong> Container supports both global and local instances for different testing strategies.</p>
            <p><strong>Recommended practice:</strong> Use local container instances for unit tests, avoid global state in test suites, and prefer constructor injection for testability.</p>
            <h3>Configuration Drift</h3>
            <p><strong>Risk:</strong> Runtime binding changes can make application behavior unpredictable.</p>
            <p><strong>Why it matters:</strong> Dynamic service registration could lead to inconsistent behavior across requests.</p>
            <p><strong>Design stance:</strong> Bindings are designed to be immutable after bootstrap to ensure consistency.</p>
            <p><strong>Recommended practice:</strong> Perform all configuration during bootstrap, avoid runtime binding modifications, and use feature flags for conditional behavior.</p>
        </section>

        <section id="related-files-folders" class="section content-card">
            <h2>Related Files &amp; Folders</h2>
            <ul>
                <li><strong>Parent folder:</strong> N/A (this is the root)</li>
                <li><strong>Sibling files:</strong> Container.php (main facade), Container.txt (documentation notes)</li>
                <li><strong>Child folders:</strong>
                    <ul>
                        <li><strong>Core:</strong> Essential container infrastructure (kernel, resolution engine)</li>
                        <li><strong>Features:</strong> Extended capabilities (advanced injection, scoping)</li>
                        <li><strong>Guard:</strong> Security and policy enforcement</li>
                        <li><strong>Observe:</strong> Monitoring, metrics, and diagnostics</li>
                        <li><strong>Providers:</strong> Pre-built service integrations</li>
                        <li><strong>tests:</strong> Test suites and fixtures</li>
                        <li><strong>Tools:</strong> CLI utilities for development</li>
                    </ul>
                </li>
            </ul>
            <p><strong>Reading order:</strong> Start with Container.php, then Core/ContainerKernel.php, then explore features based on your needs.</p>
        </section>
    </main>
</div>
</body>
</html>

            <div class="nav-section">
                <h3 class="nav-title">Resolve/Pipes</h3>

    <main class="content">
        <div class="hero">
            <h1>Master Prompt</h1>
            <p>This page repeats the universal, book-like documentation rules and PHPDoc strategy you asked me to keep for every generated page.</p>
            <div class="meta">
                <strong>File Path:</strong> docs/master-prompt.html<br>
                <strong>Folder Context:</strong> Book-style guidance<br>
                <strong>Generated:</strong> 2026-01-08
            </div>
        </div>

        <section class="section content-card">
            <h2>Quick Summary</h2>
            <p>The master prompt defines a recurring cycle: walk every folder, build book-like documentation for every file, and enhance PHPDoc so docs and code reinforce each other. Think of it as the constitution that turns every doc drop into a living, interlinked guide.</p>
        </section>

        <section class="section content-card">
            <h2>Prompt Content</h2>
            <p>This document captures the exact master prompt you shared. It's your canonical instruction set for future documentation runs.</p>
            <pre><code>You are a senior software architect, PHP expert, and technical writer.

Your task is to:
1) Generate HUMAN-GRADE, BOOK-LIKE HTML documentation
2) Improve PHP source code by adding or fixing PHPDoc blocks
3) Link code and documentation together bidirectionally
...
Let the documentation fully breathe.</code></pre>
        </section>

        <section class="section content-card">
            <h2>Why It Matters</h2>
            <ul>
                <li>It enforces a recursive folder walk so no file or folder gets skipped.</li>
                <li>It turns folders into chapters and files into sections inside the book layout.</li>
                <li>It pairs every documented concept with @see links in the PHPDoc so code and prose stay synchronized.</li>
            </ul>
        </section>

        <section class="section content-card">
            <h2>Navigation Reminder</h2>
            <p>Use the sidebar to hop between the CLI-inspired master prompt, the root summary, and the core class references. Each link follows the folder structure you asked for.</p>
        </section>
    </main>
</div>
</body>
</html>

    <main class="content">
        <div class="hero">
            <h1>{{HERO_TITLE}}</h1>
            <p>{{HERO_DESCRIPTION}}</p>
            <div class="meta">
                <strong>File Path:</strong> {{FILE_PATH}}<br>
                <strong>Folder Context:</strong> {{FOLDER_CONTEXT}}<br>
                <strong>Generated:</strong> {{GENERATED_DATE}}
            </div>
        </div>
        {{CONTENT}}
    </main>
</div>

<script>
// CKEditor integration for documentation editing
class DocEditor {
    constructor() {
        this.editors = new Map();
        this.isEditMode = this.checkEditPermission();
        this.init();
    }

    checkEditPermission() {
        // Simple permission check - can be enhanced with authentication
        const urlParams = new URLSearchParams(window.location.search);
        return urlParams.has('edit') || localStorage.getItem('doc-editor-enabled') === 'true';
    }

    init() {
        if (this.isEditMode) {
            this.addEditControls();
            this.makeContentEditable();
        }
    }

    addEditControls() {
        const hero = document.querySelector('.hero');
        if (hero) {
            const controls = document.createElement('div');
            controls.className = 'edit-controls';
            controls.innerHTML = `
                <button onclick="docEditor.toggleEditMode()">Exit Edit Mode</button>
                <button onclick="docEditor.saveAll()">Save All Changes</button>
                <button onclick="docEditor.previewChanges()">Preview</button>
                <span style="margin-left: 20px; color: #666;">Edit mode active</span>
            `;
            hero.appendChild(controls);
        }
    }

    makeContentEditable() {
        // Make sections editable
        const sections = document.querySelectorAll('.section');
        sections.forEach((section, index) => {
            section.style.position = 'relative';

            // Add edit button
            const editBtn = document.createElement('button');
            editBtn.textContent = 'Edit';
            editBtn.style.position = 'absolute';
            editBtn.style.top = '10px';
            editBtn.style.right = '10px';
            editBtn.style.zIndex = '1000';
            editBtn.onclick = () => this.enableCKEditor(section, index);
            section.appendChild(editBtn);

            // Add visual indicator
            section.classList.add('edit-mode');
        });
    }

    async enableCKEditor(section, index) {
        if (this.editors.has(index)) {
            return; // Already editing
        }

        const content = section.querySelector('.card') || section;
        if (!content) return;

        try {
            const editor = await ClassicEditor.create(content, {
                toolbar: [
                    'heading', '|',
                    'bold', 'italic', 'link', '|',
                    'bulletedList', 'numberedList', 'blockQuote', '|',
                    'codeBlock', 'insertTable', '|',
                    'undo', 'redo'
                ],
                codeBlock: {
                    languages: [
                        { language: 'php', label: 'PHP' },
                        { language: 'javascript', label: 'JavaScript' },
                        { language: 'html', label: 'HTML' },
                        { language: 'css', label: 'CSS' }
                    ]
                }
            });

            this.editors.set(index, { editor, section });

            // Update button
            const editBtn = section.querySelector('button');
            if (editBtn) {
                editBtn.textContent = 'Save';
                editBtn.onclick = () => this.saveSection(index);
            }

        } catch (error) {
            console.error('Failed to initialize CKEditor:', error);
            alert('Failed to initialize editor. Please try again.');
        }
    }

    saveSection(index) {
        const editorData = this.editors.get(index);
        if (editorData) {
            const content = editorData.editor.getData();
            console.log('Section content to save:', content);

            // Here you would send to your backend
            this.showSaveDialog(content, index);
        }
    }

    saveAll() {
        const allContent = {};
        this.editors.forEach((editorData, index) => {
            allContent[index] = editorData.editor.getData();
        });

        console.log('All content to save:', allContent);
        this.showSaveDialog(JSON.stringify(allContent, null, 2), 'all');
    }

    showSaveDialog(content, identifier) {
        // Create a modal-like overlay for save options
        const overlay = document.createElement('div');
        overlay.style.cssText = `
            position: fixed; top: 0; left: 0; right: 0; bottom: 0;
            background: rgba(0,0,0,0.5); z-index: 10000;
            display: flex; align-items: center; justify-content: center;
        `;

        overlay.innerHTML = `
            <div style="background: white; padding: 20px; border-radius: 8px; max-width: 600px; width: 90%;">
                <h3>Save Changes</h3>
                <p>The edited content needs to be saved to your documentation source.</p>
                <div style="margin: 20px 0;">
                    <strong>Content to save:</strong><br>
                    <textarea style="width: 100%; height: 200px; margin-top: 10px;" readonly>${content.substring(0, 500)}${content.length > 500 ? '...' : ''}</textarea>
                </div>
                <div style="margin-top: 20px; padding-top: 20px; border-top: 1px solid #dee2e6;">
                    <p><strong>To implement saving:</strong></p>
                    <ul>
                        <li>Create a PHP endpoint to receive POST data</li>
                        <li>Update your docs.txt or source files</li>
                        <li>Regenerate HTML documentation</li>
                        <li>Add authentication/authorization</li>
                    </ul>
                </div>
                <div style="text-align: right; margin-top: 20px;">
                    <button onclick="this.closest('div').parentElement.remove()">Close</button>
                </div>
            </div>
        `;

        document.body.appendChild(overlay);
    }

    previewChanges() {
        // Toggle preview mode
        document.body.classList.toggle('preview-mode');
        const btn = document.querySelector('button[onclick*="previewChanges"]');
        if (btn) {
            btn.textContent = document.body.classList.contains('preview-mode') ? 'Exit Preview' : 'Preview';
        }
    }

    toggleEditMode() {
        if (confirm('Exit edit mode? Unsaved changes will be lost.')) {
            localStorage.removeItem('doc-editor-enabled');
            window.location.reload();
        }
    }
}

// Initialize when DOM is ready
document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', () => {
    window.docEditor = new DocEditor();
});

// Add URL parameter handling for easy access
if (window.location.search.includes('edit')) {
    localStorage.setItem('doc-editor-enabled', 'true');
}
</script>

</body>
</html>
